Email Archive - Archive 2005 (10565 messages) (Part 6 of 6)

← Previous
1. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 and 5x5x5
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 23:18:52 -0000

I have a few of each, and in each case the Studio 4x4x4 is looser than a Winning Moves 4x4x4. However the appearance is identical, including the stickers. So it makes me think they are not made in the same place as the Studio 3x3x3. Maybe they are just assembled in a different factory, where the adjustments are made differently, hence the different feel. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > Of course you're right Stefan. But I always assume people don't take > my word as the absolute truth :P > I have 1 Rubiks.com and 2 Studio's. Ton told me the plastics were not > the same. > And I'm not complaining, since the studios were very cheap at the > Dutch Cube Day > > - Koen > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Koen Heltzel" > > <allyourbase@h...> wrote: > > > > > > Rubiks studio 4x4 is NOT the same as 4x4 Rubiks.com > > > Different plastic I think, and again I prefer Rubiks.com. Turns much > > > smoother. And yes I have both :P > > > > > > - Koen > > > > Mmh... makes me think about people who claim the 25th anni cubes are > > great and others who claim they suck, the explanation being that > > they're not all equal. Could it be you just luckily got a good rubiks. > > com 4x4 and unluckily got a bad studio 4x4? Youre preference is based > > on experience with how many of each? > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > >
2. Re: [Speed cubing group] most turns without regripping
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 01:03:01 -0000

Yah, David Barr was there and I remember walking up after too...It was pretty intense...he had a full grip on the cube... Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > I saw it but I was not very close. Ron was the one counting (and there > was a third person too, but I can't remember who it was). > And no, he didn't do anything weird such as starting in the back. > > I think the rules you say are correct and that's what I'm doing too. :-) > > 2005/12/20, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@g...>: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > Hello, > > > > > > I was rethinking about that record that happenned during the WC : 6 > > > full turns without regripping made by Oliver Wolff. > > > > > > I tried to reach it but the most I can do is 5. > > > I was wondering if anybody had any technique to be able to add a > > full > > > turn and twist your arms 6 times :p > > > > I heard about Oliver's 6 and tried it myself, all I can get is 5, too. > > Somehow I think Oliver and the people watching him all counted wrong : > > -) > > > > Did you see him do it? Did he do some weird behind-the-back stuff? > > Were there some rules? For myself, I made up this: Hold the cube with > > two fingers of each hand on opposite sides. I use thumb and middle > > finger. > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
3. Re: Different versions of the 25th anniv. cube
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 05:48:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y.. > .> wrote: > > > > If it's too tight, take it apart > > and wedge a credit card or two bewteen the center edges for a day > > or two to loosen up the tension in the springs. > Does anybody have proof this works for current rubiks.com cubes? I > > believe it for Studio cubes but I have doubts about rubiks.com > ones... > > Cheers! > Stefan I have firsthand experience this works wonders, although on a storebought cube. I tried it on what was possibly the tightest and most terrible cube I've ever played with. Coupled with a lot of grinding solves, and it's now my best speedcube. Thank you Wal-Mart. :) -Mike Bennett

5. Re: [Speed cubing group] most turns without regripping
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 08:30:47 +0100

No, there is only one face to turn, and of course you can't change the direction (clockwise or anti-clockwise) during the attempt. ;-) Gilles. 2005/12/21, Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...>: > I'm so confused about what this is actually referring to. If it's > just consecutive turns without regripping, wouldn't ((F4R4)^until your > arms fall off) work? > > -Mike > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > I saw it but I was not very close. Ron was the one counting (and there > > > was a third person too, but I can't remember who it was). > > > And no, he didn't do anything weird such as starting in the back. > > > > > > I think the rules you say are correct and that's what I'm doing > too. :-) > > > > > > 2005/12/20, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@g...>: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Hello, > > > > > > > > > > I was rethinking about that record that happenned during the > WC : 6 > > > > > full turns without regripping made by Oliver Wolff. > > > > > > > > > > I tried to reach it but the most I can do is 5. > > > > > I was wondering if anybody had any technique to be able to add a > > > > full > > > > > turn and twist your arms 6 times :p > > > > > > > > I heard about Oliver's 6 and tried it myself, all I can get is > 5, too. > > > > Somehow I think Oliver and the people watching him all counted > wrong : > > > > -) > > > > > > > > Did you see him do it? 6. Re: rubiks studio
From: "darereck" <darereck@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 07:34:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "washyourmonkey" <washyourmonkey@y...> wrote: > > how can i get a rubiks studio cube and do they have solid corner pieces. > You can probably find them on ebay once in a while but they go for high prices like $50 or so. Yeah they have solid corners. I have one and its pretty nice, plus you could adjust the tension. I'd say buy one if your planning to speedcube but if your just a casual cubist then stick with a 25th aniversary since they are cheaper.
7. Re: [Speed cubing group] new version of Jess Bonde's ultimate timer featuring scrambled applets
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 13:13:55 +0530

Sorry for my ignorance, but i cannot see any applet loading up on the link u gave me. I think it still needs to be updated. And could u post a link to ur files section? I am trying all sorts of things like /files, /temp but i get the "under construction" page for the root link Sachin. On 12/21/05, Michiel van der Blonk <blonkm@...> wrote: > Hi > > I created a new version of Jess Bonde's ultimate timer even though I > know he promised to rip my head off... > > No, in fact I did ask him to create a version that would contain an > applet to immediately be able to check the scramble on your cube, > but he said the code was so ugly he'd probably die from the mere > shock of looking at it. > > I took my chances anyway, and it was only a couple of lines to be > added. > > If you want to change the color scheme then you can search for it in > the source code and do so, it's in one place only (hint: search > for "<applet"). > > You can download it from the files section, or use it online here: > http://vanderblonk.com/cube/timer.htm > > Make sure you put the rubikplayer.jar from www.randelshofer.ch in > the same directory as the file, and Ron's your uncle! > > Michiel > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
8. Petrus method
From: "washyourmonkey" <washyourmonkey@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 08:06:15 -0000

is there anyone else out there there that uses the petrus method that
could give me some pointers that might help me break the 30 limit. im
curently doing low to mid 30's and just about every vid ive seen is
someone using fridrich.

oh and are there any good timer apps for linux or any at all for that
matter?

Would be good to meet up for a bit. > > Oh, and I promise I'll come to the next UK meet :D > > ~Thom > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > <duncan@d...> wrote: >> >> Hi Matt >> Welcome to the UK speedcubing community. Hopefully we will have > another get >> together, perhaps in the summer. It would be great to see you there. >> It soudns like you are making good progress already - maybe you will be >> giving Dan a run for his money one day. >> >> Good luck and Happy Christmas >> >> Duncan >> (you can e-mail or messenger me at duncandicks@h... direct if you >> fancy a UK chat) >> >> ----- Original Message ----- >> From: "mantawrays" <matt.williams@l...> >> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> >> Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 5:25 PM >> Subject: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber >> >> >> > Hi! A new cuber in the UK here. I used to play with the cube in the >> > 80's when I was little(I used a really simple beginner layer method, I >> > think) and recently after playing with a 4 x 4 someone in the office >> > had got hooked again and bought a new cube in August. >> > >> > I've been reading a lot of the people here's web pages and they have >> > all been a great help (esp. Jessica Fridrich's, Dan Harris', Joel Van >> > Noort, Chris Hardwick's). So thanks to everyone for making some great >> > webpages. I use the cross on the bottom. I am getting better at doing >> > F2L (it's taking a long time to be able to make fast decisions >> > though!) and have learnt the U, Z, H, E, J and F PLL algorithms (and >> > have forgotten the A one!). I guess I'm going to try to learn all the >> > PLL ones and then look at the OLL ones. Is that the general approach >> > to learning Fridrich? Since I learnt those PLL's I have found it >> > possible to solve the cube in around 50 seconds whereas before it was >> > around 1 minute 30 or something like that if I went flat out. Still >> > pretty slow compared to everyone here. >> > >> > Still, I had a go with Chris H's 'oh wow' scramble and was shocked >> > when using my method after a few tries I solved it in 31 seconds. >> > Well, That was a big Oh wow for me, anyway! :) >> > >> > I have two cubes, one I bought from a department store in August with >> > bright stickers on (which deteriorated really rapidly )- probably the >> > generic 3 x 3 Rubiks.com sell, and a Rubik's 3 x 3 DIY cube with PVC >> > stickers which I prefer. The DIY one seems to be easier to control >> > turns on and more suitable for doing fast solves (although it's >> > noisier according to my wife). Oh yes, and it has M0105B written on >> > one of the corners. >> > >> > Does anyone have any opinions of the new anniversary cube? Is it the >> > same as the normal 3 x 3 but with a different centre white sticker? Is >> > it at all suitable for speedcubing? Are the stickers PVC or > polypropelene? >> > >> > That's it for now. >> > >> > Cheers, Matt >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > Yahoo! Groups Links >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
10. Re: Petrus method
From: "Paul Nixon" <yahoo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 09:38:49 -0000

hello mr washyourmonkey i used the petrus method for about a year. i recently jumped ship to fridrich (about 3 months ago) and i'm already doing faster times. in fairness this could be partly because there are certain aspects of the petrus method that i never really got the hang off; in particular colour neutrality. however, i did achieve a best time of 23.5x and an average fractionally under 30 albeit not in competition :-(, albeit that's not much quiker than you anyway here are a couple of things that you might want to consider that improved my times 1. switch to oll/pll for the last layer. and find some decent algorithms that suit you. the good thing about petrus is that, with edges flipped correctly on the last layer the burden of oll is vastly reduced. a further benefit is that, if you do want to switch methods in the future, you're half way there. 2. step 4 algorithms. spend some time with the wonderful cubesolver (http://www.speedcubing.com/CubeSolver/CubeSolver.html) and learn some optimal algs for the positions, especially for the last corner-edge pair. i used to burn a lot of moves in this stage. 3. find algorithms that suit your style. i used/misused a few algs from the petrus site for the last layer that didn't really suit my style. take advantage of the considerable amount of work that has been done on the fridrich based solution and learn some nicer algs. 4. find the 'leaks'. do some slow solves and note where your method is inefficient. then work on these areas using cubesolver/acube. 5. consider joining duncan dicks on his l2l2 quest. the petrus 2x3x3 is a good starting point for this promising method and i've generated the algorithms in acube if you're interested in taking this on. unfortunately i got a bit bogged down in algorithm learning and then fell for f2l pairs :-) cheers paul --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "washyourmonkey" <washyourmonkey@y...> wrote: > > is there anyone else out there there that uses the petrus method that > could give me some pointers that might help me break the 30 limit. im > curently doing low to mid 30's and just about every vid ive seen is > someone using fridrich. > > oh and are there any good timer apps for linux or any at all for that > matter? >

Yeah they have solid corners. Depends on how you define "solid". They are closed with caps, but they are hollow inside. Cheers! Stefan

Thanks, Thom. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@f...> wrote: > > Hi Thom, > > I'm an Australian currently based in London (although flying back to > Australia tomorrow for a month). Duncan hosted the first UK cubers > gathering earlier this year and we all had a great time! Thom - where > are you based? > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > On Wed, 21 Dec 2005 08:15:38 -0000, "Duncan Dicks" > <duncan@d...> said: > > > > Hi Thom! > > Im in Gloucestershire - Id be happy to host the next get > > together too. > > Duncan > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@g...> > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 10:20 PM > > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber > > > Hey > > > > > > I'm another UK'r to say hi :) > > > > > > Where abouts in the UK are you based? A new cuber in the UK here. I used to play with the > > cube in the > > >> > 80's when I was little(I used a really simple beginner > > layer method, I > > >> > think) and recently after playing with a 4 x 4 someone in > > the office > > >> > had got hooked again and bought a new cube in August. > > >> > > > >> > I've been reading a lot of the people here's web pages and > > they have > > >> > all been a great help (esp. Jessica Fridrich's, Dan > > Harris', Joel Van > > >> > Noort, Chris Hardwick's). So thanks to everyone for making > > some great > > >> > webpages. I use the cross on the bottom. I am getting > > better at doing > > >> > F2L (it's taking a long time to be able to make fast > > decisions > > >> > though!) and have learnt the U, Z, H, E, J and F PLL > > algorithms (and > > >> > have forgotten the A one!). I guess I'm going to try to > > learn all the > > >> > PLL ones and then look at the OLL ones. Is that the general > > approach > > >> > to learning Fridrich? Since I learnt those PLL's I have > > found it > > >> > possible to solve the cube in around 50 seconds whereas > > before it was > > >> > around 1 minute 30 or something like that if I went flat > > out. Still > > >> > pretty slow compared to everyone here. > > >> > > > >> > Still, I had a go with Chris H's 'oh wow' scramble and was > > shocked > > >> > when using my method after a few tries I solved it in 31 > > seconds. > > >> > Well, That was a big Oh wow for me, anyway! :) > > >> > > > >> > I have two cubes, one I bought from a department store in > > August with > > >> > bright stickers on (which deteriorated really rapidly )- > > probably the > > >> > generic 3 x 3 Rubiks.com sell, and a Rubik's 3 x 3 DIY cube > > with PVC > > >> > stickers which I prefer. The DIY one seems to be easier to > > control > > >> > turns on and more suitable for doing fast solves (although > > it's > > >> > noisier according to my wife). Oh yes, and it has M0105B > > written on > > >> > one of the corners. > > >> > > > >> > Does anyone have any opinions of the new anniversary cube? > > Is it the > > >> > same as the normal 3 x 3 but with a different centre white > > sticker? Is > > >> > it at all suitable for speedcubing? Are the stickers PVC or > > > polypropelene? > > >> > > > >> > That's it for now. > > >> > > > >> > Cheers, Matt > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > > > >> > Yahoo! On 12/21/05, Michiel van der Blonk <blonkm@...> wrote: > Hi > > I created a new version of Jess Bonde's ultimate timer even though I > know he promised to rip my head off... > > No, in fact I did ask him to create a version that would contain an > applet to immediately be able to check the scramble on your cube, > but he said the code was so ugly he'd probably die from the mere > shock of looking at it. > > I took my chances anyway, and it was only a couple of lines to be > added. > > If you want to change the color scheme then you can search for it in > the source code and do so, it's in one place only (hint: search > for "<applet"). > > You can download it from the files section, or use it online here: > http://vanderblonk.com/cube/timer.htm > > Make sure you put the rubikplayer.jar from www.randelshofer.ch in > the same directory as the file, and Ron's your uncle! > > Michiel > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. 18. Re: [Speed cubing group] new version of Jess Bonde's ultimate timer featuring scrambled applets
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 09:17:43 -0300 (ART)

Sachin, the files section is the speedcubing group files section. The html file is there. You have to put the file on the same folder where the rubikplayer.jar is, other way the applets will not load. Pedro Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...> escreveu: Sorry for my ignorance, but i cannot see any applet loading up on the link u gave me. I think it still needs to be updated. And could u post a link to ur files section? I am trying all sorts of things like /files, /temp but i get the "under construction" page for the root link Sachin. 19. Re: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 12:19:10 -0000

Hi Thom, Unfortunately we all live miles away from each other! My best is still 29.xx average although now I'm using L2L2 full time I'm hoping that will come down. In the last few days and without too much practice my L2L2 average has come down to around 32-33 seconds. My 29.xx is L2L1 and L2L2 is quite a bit more efficient so with a bit more practice I'm expecting better times. A friend of mine (John White) who used to be a speedcuber 20+ years ago lives up near you (liverpool) but he hasn't caught onto the revival. Pity - he was faster than me and also held the blindfold world record! best wishes Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 11:55 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber > Hey, I'm based in manchester. > > I was going to come to the meetup at Dan house (the last one) but > never made it due to some unforseen circumstances :S.... > > Unfortunatly I appear to live miles away from all the other UK cubers. > Not to fear, I'll sort something out :) > > What are your times like these days? (Duncan and Jasmine), I don't > really wanna be shown up at my first meetup :P > > Duncan - are you using a full L2L(1-4) method? If so, which? > > Thanks, Thom. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jasmine Lee" > <speedcuber@f...> wrote: >> >> Hi Thom, >> >> I'm an Australian currently based in London (although flying back to >> Australia tomorrow for a month). It would be great to see >> > you there. >> > >> It soudns like you are making good progress already - maybe >> > you will be >> > >> giving Dan a run for his money one day. >> > >> >> > >> Good luck and Happy Christmas >> > >> >> > >> Duncan >> > >> (you can e-mail or messenger me at duncandicks@h... direct if >> > you >> > >> fancy a UK chat) >> > >> >> > >> ----- Original Message ----- >> > >> From: "mantawrays" <matt.williams@l...> >> > >> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> >> > >> Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 5:25 PM >> > >> Subject: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber >> > >> >> > >> >> > >> > Hi! A new cuber in the UK here. I used to play with the >> > cube in the >> > >> > 80's when I was little(I used a really simple beginner >> > layer method, I >> > >> > think) and recently after playing with a 4 x 4 someone in >> > the office >> > >> > had got hooked again and bought a new cube in August. >> > >> > >> > >> > I've been reading a lot of the people here's web pages and >> > they have >> > >> > all been a great help (esp. Jessica Fridrich's, Dan >> > Harris', Joel Van >> > >> > Noort, Chris Hardwick's). So thanks to everyone for making >> > some great >> > >> > webpages. I use the cross on the bottom. I am getting >> > better at doing >> > >> > F2L (it's taking a long time to be able to make fast >> > decisions >> > >> > though!) and have learnt the U, Z, H, E, J and F PLL >> > algorithms (and >> > >> > have forgotten the A one!). I guess I'm going to try to >> > learn all the >> > >> > PLL ones and then look at the OLL ones. Is that the general >> > approach >> > >> > to learning Fridrich? Since I learnt those PLL's I have >> > found it >> > >> > possible to solve the cube in around 50 seconds whereas >> > before it was >> > >> > around 1 minute 30 or something like that if I went flat >> > out. Still >> > >> > pretty slow compared to everyone here. >> > >> > >> > >> > Still, I had a go with Chris H's 'oh wow' scramble and was >> > shocked >> > >> > when using my method after a few tries I solved it in 31 >> > seconds. >> > >> > Well, That was a big Oh wow for me, anyway! :) >> > >> > >> > >> > I have two cubes, one I bought from a department store in >> > August with >> > >> > bright stickers on (which deteriorated really rapidly )- >> > probably the >> > >> > generic 3 x 3 Rubiks.com sell, and a Rubik's 3 x 3 DIY cube >> > with PVC >> > >> > stickers which I prefer. The DIY one seems to be easier to >> > control >> > >> > turns on and more suitable for doing fast solves (although >> > it's >> > >> > noisier according to my wife). Oh yes, and it has M0105B >> > written on >> > >> > one of the corners. >> > >> > >> > >> > Does anyone have any opinions of the new anniversary cube? >> > Is it the >> > >> > same as the normal 3 x 3 but with a different centre white >> > sticker? Is >> > >> > it at all suitable for speedcubing? Are the stickers PVC or >> > > polypropelene? >> > >> > >> > >> > That's it for now. >> > >> > >> > >> > Cheers, Matt >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > >> > Yahoo! Duncan hosted the first UK cubers > > >> gathering earlier this year and we all had a great time! A new cuber in the UK here. I used to play with the > > >> > cube in the > > >> > >> > 80's when I was little(I used a really simple beginner > > >> > layer method, I > > >> > >> > think) and recently after playing with a 4 x 4 someone in > > >> > the office > > >> > >> > had got hooked again and bought a new cube in August. > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > I've been reading a lot of the people here's web pages and > > >> > they have > > >> > >> > all been a great help (esp. Jessica Fridrich's, Dan > > >> > Harris', Joel Van > > >> > >> > Noort, Chris Hardwick's). So thanks to everyone for making > > >> > some great > > >> > >> > webpages. I use the cross on the bottom. I am getting > > >> > better at doing > > >> > >> > F2L (it's taking a long time to be able to make fast > > >> > decisions > > >> > >> > though!) and have learnt the U, Z, H, E, J and F PLL > > >> > algorithms (and > > >> > >> > have forgotten the A one!). I guess I'm going to try to > > >> > learn all the > > >> > >> > PLL ones and then look at the OLL ones. Is that the general > > >> > approach > > >> > >> > to learning Fridrich? Since I learnt those PLL's I have > > >> > found it > > >> > >> > possible to solve the cube in around 50 seconds whereas > > >> > before it was > > >> > >> > around 1 minute 30 or something like that if I went flat > > >> > out. Still > > >> > >> > pretty slow compared to everyone here. > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > Still, I had a go with Chris H's 'oh wow' scramble and was > > >> > shocked > > >> > >> > when using my method after a few tries I solved it in 31 > > >> > seconds. > > >> > >> > Well, That was a big Oh wow for me, anyway! :) > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > I have two cubes, one I bought from a department store in > > >> > August with > > >> > >> > bright stickers on (which deteriorated really rapidly )- > > >> > probably the > > >> > >> > generic 3 x 3 Rubiks.com sell, and a Rubik's 3 x 3 DIY cube > > >> > with PVC > > >> > >> > stickers which I prefer. The DIY one seems to be easier to > > >> > control > > >> > >> > turns on and more suitable for doing fast solves (although > > >> > it's > > >> > >> > noisier according to my wife). Oh yes, and it has M0105B > > >> > written on > > >> > >> > one of the corners. > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > Does anyone have any opinions of the new anniversary cube? > > >> > Is it the > > >> > >> > same as the normal 3 x 3 but with a different centre white > > >> > sticker? Is > > >> > >> > it at all suitable for speedcubing? Are the stickers PVC or > > >> > > polypropelene? > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > That's it for now. > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > Cheers, Matt > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > > > >> > >> > Yahoo! 22. Re: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber
From: "mantawrays" <matt.williams@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 13:06:16 -0000

Hi there, I'm based in Bristol so sounds like we're close... I like the idea of meeting up at some point since no-one I know is into it at all so it's a lonely process learning it from the web. And slow, too! Finding time to do this will be pretty hard I have to say. I'm a bit older than most of the people here and have a young family! Anything's possible I suppose. If it's in Gloucestershire it will be easier! No chance of getting anywhere near Dan no matter how much I practice, I think but it will be fun trying! My problem is I keep forgetting the algorithms I never use and my fingers aren't as fast as they used to be. If I could consistently get near 30 I would be more than happy! Don't quite understand what the L2L(1-4) method refers to.. is it layers or number of times you look or...? Is it Fridrich at all? Cheers, Matt --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@g...> wrote: > > Hey > > I'm another UK'r to say hi :) > > Where abouts in the UK are you based? Would be good to meet up for a bit. > > Oh, and I promise I'll come to the next UK meet :D > > ~Thom > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > <duncan@d...> wrote: > > > > Hi Matt > > Welcome to the UK speedcubing community. It would be great to see you there. > > It soudns like you are making good progress already - maybe you will be > > giving Dan a run for his money one day. > > > > Good luck and Happy Christmas > > > > Duncan > > (you can e-mail or messenger me at duncandicks@h... direct if you > > fancy a UK chat) > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "mantawrays" <matt.williams@l...> > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > Sent: Tuesday, December 20, 2005 5:25 PM > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber > > > > > > > Hi! A new cuber in the UK here. I used to play with the cube in the > > > 80's when I was little(I used a really simple beginner layer method, I > > > think) and recently after playing with a 4 x 4 someone in the office > > > had got hooked again and bought a new cube in August. > > > > > > I've been reading a lot of the people here's web pages and they have > > > all been a great help (esp. Jessica Fridrich's, Dan Harris', Joel Van > > > Noort, Chris Hardwick's). So thanks to everyone for making some great > > > webpages. I use the cross on the bottom. I am getting better at doing > > > F2L (it's taking a long time to be able to make fast decisions > > > though!) and have learnt the U, Z, H, E, J and F PLL algorithms (and > > > have forgotten the A one!). I guess I'm going to try to learn all the > > > PLL ones and then look at the OLL ones. Is that the general approach > > > to learning Fridrich? Since I learnt those PLL's I have found it > > > possible to solve the cube in around 50 seconds whereas before it was > > > around 1 minute 30 or something like that if I went flat out. Still > > > pretty slow compared to everyone here. > > > > > > Still, I had a go with Chris H's 'oh wow' scramble and was shocked > > > when using my method after a few tries I solved it in 31 seconds. > > > Well, That was a big Oh wow for me, anyway! :) > > > > > > I have two cubes, one I bought from a department store in August with > > > bright stickers on (which deteriorated really rapidly )- probably the > > > generic 3 x 3 Rubiks.com sell, and a Rubik's 3 x 3 DIY cube with PVC > > > stickers which I prefer. The DIY one seems to be easier to control > > > turns on and more suitable for doing fast solves (although it's > > > noisier according to my wife). Oh yes, and it has M0105B written on > > > one of the corners. > > > > > > Does anyone have any opinions of the new anniversary cube? Is it the > > > same as the normal 3 x 3 but with a different centre white sticker? Is > > > it at all suitable for speedcubing? Are the stickers PVC or > polypropelene? > > > > > > That's it for now. > > > > > > Cheers, Matt > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 24. Re: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 13:16:25 -0000

Hi Matt, I'm also older than most people here and with kids. I'm in Stroud though occasionally have jobs in Bristol. The L2L strategies are my method and can be found on http://mysite.wanadoo-members.co.uk/cubertscubicle Its not a great website I'm afraid :( L2L refers to Last 2 Layers as opposed to Fridrich and First 2 Layers. The method avoids or significantly buts down the last layer element of Fridrich by doing parts of the last layer while putting in middle layer edges. Its a little more efficient on moves than Fridrich and requires fewer algorithms to learn. However the Fridrich algorithms have been optimised by many people for speed of execution and my L2L ones haven't. Still in principle its easier to learn and faster. best wishes Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "mantawrays" <matt.williams@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 1:06 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] New UK cuber > Hi there, > > I'm based in Bristol so sounds like we're close... > > I like the idea of meeting up at some point since no-one I know is > into it at all so it's a lonely process learning it from the web. And > slow, too! > > Finding time to do this will be pretty hard I have to say. I'm a bit > older than most of the people here and have a young family! Anything's > possible I suppose. If it's in Gloucestershire it will be easier! > > No chance of getting anywhere near Dan no matter how much I practice, > I think but it will be fun trying! My problem is I keep forgetting the > algorithms I never use and my fingers aren't as fast as they used to > be. If I could consistently get near 30 I would be more than happy! > > Don't quite understand what the L2L(1-4) method refers to.. is it > layers or number of times you look or...? Is it Fridrich at all? > > Cheers, Matt > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "thomkirjava" > <snkenjoi@g...> wrote: >> >> Hey >> >> I'm another UK'r to say hi :) >> >> Where abouts in the UK are you based? Jessica Fridrich's, Dan Harris', > Joel Van >> > > Noort, Chris Hardwick's). So thanks to everyone for making some > great >> > > webpages. I use the cross on the bottom. I am getting better at > doing >> > > F2L (it's taking a long time to be able to make fast decisions >> > > though!) and have learnt the U, Z, H, E, J and F PLL algorithms (and >> > > have forgotten the A one!). I guess I'm going to try to learn > all the >> > > PLL ones and then look at the OLL ones. Is that the general approach >> > > to learning Fridrich? Since I learnt those PLL's I have found it >> > > possible to solve the cube in around 50 seconds whereas before > it was >> > > around 1 minute 30 or something like that if I went flat out. Still >> > > pretty slow compared to everyone here. >> > > >> > > Still, I had a go with Chris H's 'oh wow' scramble and was shocked >> > > when using my method after a few tries I solved it in 31 seconds. >> > > Well, That was a big Oh wow for me, anyway! :) >> > > >> > > I have two cubes, one I bought from a department store in August > with >> > > bright stickers on (which deteriorated really rapidly )- > probably the >> > > generic 3 x 3 Rubiks.com sell, and a Rubik's 3 x 3 DIY cube with PVC >> > > stickers which I prefer. The DIY one seems to be easier to control >> > > turns on and more suitable for doing fast solves (although it's >> > > noisier according to my wife). Oh yes, and it has M0105B written on >> > > one of the corners. >> > > >> > > Does anyone have any opinions of the new anniversary cube? Is it the >> > > same as the normal 3 x 3 but with a different centre white > sticker? Is >> > > it at all suitable for speedcubing? And while u are at it, pls add an option for 5x5x5 cube ;-) Oh, one more thing. The applet should be one of those floating favlets or whatever it was called ;-) So the user can move it to preferred location. Cheers! -Per --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@z...> wrote: > > Hi > > I created a new version of Jess Bonde's ultimate timer even though I > know he promised to rip my head off... > > No, in fact I did ask him to create a version that would contain an > applet to immediately be able to check the scramble on your cube, > but he said the code was so ugly he'd probably die from the mere > shock of looking at it. > > I took my chances anyway, and it was only a couple of lines to be > added. > > If you want to change the color scheme then you can search for it in > the source code and do so, it's in one place only (hint: search > for "<applet"). > > You can download it from the files section, or use it online here: > http://vanderblonk.com/cube/timer.htm > > Make sure you put the rubikplayer.jar from www.randelshofer.ch in > the same directory as the file, and Ron's your uncle! > > Michiel >
26. Re: [Speed cubing group] Your own method and algs
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 14:28:16 -0000

Hi Duncan, Does it mean that you now have all the sequences needed for the L2L in 4 steps? On your site, I can't see the ones with the unsolved middle-layer edge not in the last layer. Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > > Hi DJ, > I have all the algorithms for the complete method - its just that I havent > learned them all yet! Once I'm comfortable and faster with the 35 I use now > that eliminate OLL I'll move along and learn the last 20 which will get rid > of PLL. The moves and method are all on my (badly written!) website > http://mysite.wanadoo-members.co.uk/cubertscubicle > > Don't know your method so I don't know whether any of these algorithms would > help. > > Duncan > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Thursday, September 22, 2005 1:23 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Your own method and algs > > > > Hi Duncan, > > > > I've got the option of eliminating LL in my method, too. Once I have a > > better handle on solving the last 4 corners I can do more work on the > > last 5. How far along are you in eliminating LL? > > > > DJ > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > > <duncan@d...> wrote: > >> Use my own method (L2L) but at the moment with PLL algorithms at > > least some > >> of which are other peoples. 27. Re: [Speed cubing group] Your own method and algs
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 16:00:46 -0000

Hi Gilles, A good point Gilles. The way things are at the moment there are alternative algorithms in step 1 that will kick other middle layer edges down into the last layer. That takes care of all the cases except the one where all the middle layer edges start in the middle layer but jumbled. The reason I haven't spent time on this is because practically I do L2L2 and use other tricks instead of F2l pairs to make sure it doesn't happen. Its been a year since I first put up my website though so I am running out of excuses! If the method is ever going to be as practical as other fast strategies like your own, Fridrich and Petrus for example I need to upgrade the website and make sure it copes with every case. When I do this I will make sure that the most optimal (L2L3) solution goes up too. Thanks for pointing out my overenthusiasm! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 2:28 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Your own method and algs > > Hi Duncan, > > Does it mean that you now have all the sequences needed for the L2L in > 4 steps? On your site, I can't see the ones with the unsolved > middle-layer edge not in the last layer. > > Gilles. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > <duncan@d...> wrote: >> >> Hi DJ, >> I have all the algorithms for the complete method - its just that I > havent >> learned them all yet! 28. Re: [Speed cubing group] Your own method and algs
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 16:54:18 -0000

Well, the theory says that many more sequences are required. But, for example, chances for having the 4 middle-layer edges in the middle-layer when starting step 1 are very low ((1x2x3x4)/(5x6x7x8)). But for other steps, figures are much higher (1/15 for step 3, 1/5 for step 4). I didn't know if you had some strategy to reduce the number of cases, as some people do with Fridrich's last pair to reduce the complexity of the last layer. Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > > Hi Gilles, > A good point Gilles. The way things are at the moment there are alternative > algorithms in step 1 that will kick other middle layer edges down into the > last layer. That takes care of all the cases except the one where all the > middle layer edges start in the middle layer but jumbled. The reason I > haven't spent time on this is because practically I do L2L2 and use other > tricks instead of F2l pairs to make sure it doesn't happen. > Its been a year since I first put up my website though so I am running out > of excuses! If the method is ever going to be as practical as other fast > strategies like your own, Fridrich and Petrus for example I need to upgrade > the website and make sure it copes with every case. When I do this I will > make sure that the most optimal (L2L3) solution goes up too. > > Thanks for pointing out my overenthusiasm! > > Duncan > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 2:28 PM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Your own method and algs > > > > > > Hi Duncan, > > > > Does it mean that you now have all the sequences needed for the L2L in > > 4 steps? 29. Re: [Speed cubing group] Petrus method
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 09:25:24 -0800 (PST)

my petrus times have dropped pretty steadily over the last year and i'm averaging 27 or so right now with it. if you want to see a video check out strangepuzzle.com i have a 22.18, and lars has a couple faster than that, a 14 and 18 if i remember correctly. color neutrality is a big deal because it makes almost every scramble have a decent start, i found my biggest "leak" was in the edge flipping stage, when it was red/yellow or red/white i could tear through it, while if it was blue/orange or something like that, i'd have problems seeing all the bad edges. the biggest thing to work on, or that i work on is still assembling that first 2x2x2 box. i study the cube until i memorize the box moves, then put on a blindfold, or close my eyes and do it. this really helps the ability to look ahead which is extra crucial for the petrus. lars also recommended to me, that you should write down a box solution for every corner on a scramble, and decide which one is best, it takes some time but its a great exercise. i'm not sure who all uses the petrus method out there, but thaese are my ideas. ----- Original Message ---- From: washyourmonkey <washyourmonkey@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 00:06:15 Subject: [Speed cubing group] Petrus method is there anyone else out there there that uses the petrus method that could give me some pointers that might help me break the 30 limit. im curently doing low to mid 30's and just about every vid ive seen is someone using fridrich. oh and are there any good timer apps for linux or any at all for that matter? SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games YAHOO! 30. Re: Different versions of the 25th anniv. cube
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 17:49:24 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Only coupled with those grinding solves or did it get better just > because of the credit cards? > > Cheers! > Stefan Technically, I didn't use credit cards. I opted for plastic buttern knives instead. But those came first by about two weeks and made all the difference in the world. Two of my sides didn't turn as well as the others, and all six were too tight as it was. The butter knives helped loosen it up considerably. The grinding solves just made it a little looser, but also helped to wear down the internal corners, so now it transitions between turns better, because it doesn't need to be matched up as perfectly. -Mike
31. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Different versions of the 25th anniv. cube
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>

Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 17:58:14 +0000 (GMT)

33. RE: [Speed cubing group] Petrus method
From: "James Stuber" <jestuber@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 10:33:09 -0800

I've been messing around with Petrus/RH start where I don't orient the edges before I finish f2l. With an OLL/PLL finish I've been averaging around 21~22 or so. My normal Fridrich average is around 19 or so. I think starting with Petrus/RH and finishing with OLL/PLL has A LOT of potential with better recognition. -James Stuber _____ From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Clancy Cochran Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 9:25 AM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Petrus method my petrus times have dropped pretty steadily over the last year and i'm averaging 27 or so right now with it. if you want to see a video check out strangepuzzle.com i have a 22.18, and lars has a couple faster than that, a 14 and 18 if i remember correctly. color neutrality is a big deal because it makes almost every scramble have a decent start, i found my biggest "leak" was in the edge flipping stage, when it was red/yellow or red/white i could tear through it, while if it was blue/orange or something like that, i'd have problems seeing all the bad edges. the biggest thing to work on, or that i work on is still assembling that first 2x2x2 box. i study the cube until i memorize the box moves, then put on a blindfold, or close my eyes and do it. this really helps the ability to look ahead which is extra crucial for the petrus. lars also recommended to me, that you should write down a box solution for every corner on a scramble, and decide which one is best, it takes some time but its a great exercise. i'm not sure who all uses the petrus method out there, but thaese are my ideas. ----- Original Message ---- From: washyourmonkey <washyourmonkey@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 00:06:15 Subject: [Speed cubing group] Petrus method is there anyone else out there there that uses the petrus method that could give me some pointers that might help me break the 30 limit. im curently doing low to mid 30's and just about every vid ive seen is someone using fridrich. oh and are there any good timer apps for linux or any at all for that matter? 34. Methods

isn't very fast (my best time is 38 sec. and I've been cubing for over
a year with about an hour of practice almost every day). I hear
everyone talking about the roux method, the petrus method (the only
other one i actually know about), and all sorts of different methods.
Could anyone offer up some good websites for learning a different
method to solve a cube? I'm desperate. haha.

~John~

36. Sunes vs (O)LL
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 20:06:29 -0000

For a while I wanted to know how many sune variant applications I need
to solve OLL.

Let's say standard sune is (R U R' U R U2 R'). You can invert it, you
can mirror it, and you can do an M' setup move which simply turns the
first R into r and the last R' into r'. So you have 8 sune variants of
7 moves each. Besides this large number of easy variants, I also like
the sune for being a real simple algorithm (for beginners and for
hands :-).

So I finally wrote a program and got this result:

1 case needs 0 sunes.
6 cases need 1 sunes.
42 cases need 2 sunes.
9 cases need 3 sunes.
Average number of sunes needed: 2.01724

Next idea would be to find out how many sunes are needed (max/avg) to
solve the whole LL after corners have been permuted (because sunes
don't change the relative corner permutation).

Cheers!
Stefan






37. Re: Sunes vs (O)LL
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 20:28:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > 9 cases need 3 sunes. One of these 9 is the OLL case where the corners are correct but all four edges need to be flipped. Can you solve that with 3 sune variants? If you don't mirror but only invert and/or setup M', then this OLL case is the only one that needs four sunes, so this is somewhat the "hardest case" :-) Cheers! Stefan
38. Re: Sunes vs (O)LL
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 20:36:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > For a while I wanted to know how many sune variant applications I need > to solve OLL. > > Let's say standard sune is (R U R' U R U2 R'). You can invert it, you > can mirror it, and you can do an M' setup move which simply turns the > first R into r and the last R' into r'. So you have 8 sune variants of > 7 moves each. Besides this large number of easy variants, I also like > the sune for being a real simple algorithm (for beginners and for > hands :-). > > So I finally wrote a program and got this result: > > 1 case needs 0 sunes. > 6 cases need 1 sunes. > 42 cases need 2 sunes. > 9 cases need 3 sunes. > Average number of sunes needed: 2.01724 > > Next idea would be to find out how many sunes are needed (max/avg) to > solve the whole LL after corners have been permuted (because sunes > don't change the relative corner permutation). > > Cheers! > Stefan > Interesting. Yes, very simple sequences like the Sune, can be powerful. Mixing and optimizing 2 simple sequences give elegant solutions to complex last-layer cases, often QTM-optimal (that's why I often said I would choose this approach if I wanted to become a ZB-boy). Lars Petrus computed solutions for all last-layer cases with oriented edges, based on 2 simple sequences. He may have the answer to your question. Gilles.
39. Re: [Speed cubing group] Methods
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 20:46:25 -0000

http://www.snkenjoi.com/wikicube/mediawiki-1.5.3/index.php?title=Methods Also has short details of some methods, which will probibly help guide you in picking one. Thom says: go for roux :D ~Thom --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Fridrich: www.speedcubing.com > Petrus: http://lar5.com/cube > Roux: http:grrroux.free.fr > and a lot more... > www.cubewhiz.com > www.solvethecube.co.uk > www.cubestation.co.uk > www.nascarjon.us > > Pedro > > giraffeboy13 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> escreveu: > So, i don't know what the method i use is, but whatever it is, it > isn't very fast (my best time is 38 sec. and I've been cubing for over > a year with about an hour of practice almost every day). I hear > everyone talking about the roux method, the petrus method (the only > other one i actually know about), and all sorts of different methods. > Could anyone offer up some good websites for learning a different > method to solve a cube? 40. Re: Sunes vs (O)LL
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 22:34:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > For a while I wanted to know how many sune variant applications I need > to solve OLL. > > Let's say standard sune is (R U R' U R U2 R'). You can invert it, you > can mirror it, and you can do an M' setup move which simply turns the > first R into r and the last R' into r'. So you have 8 sune variants of > 7 moves each. Besides this large number of easy variants, I also like > the sune for being a real simple algorithm (for beginners and for > hands :-). > > So I finally wrote a program and got this result: > > 1 case needs 0 sunes. > 6 cases need 1 sunes. > 42 cases need 2 sunes. > 9 cases need 3 sunes. > Average number of sunes needed: 2.01724 > > Next idea would be to find out how many sunes are needed (max/avg) to > solve the whole LL after corners have been permuted (because sunes > don't change the relative corner permutation). > > Cheers! > Stefan Hi Stefan, COLL never needs more than 2 sunes. Not that this info helps anything. Cheers, David J

42. Re: Sunes vs (O)LL
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 00:55:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > COLL never needs more than 2 sunes. > > Not that this info helps anything. > > Cheers, > > David J > Hi David, yes, I knew that, doesn't everybody? :-) Everybody *should*... That's a method I like for team solving. When it's time to orient corners, one person simply starts a sune and the other follows it blindly. As long as the guy starts correctly, it's fine. And it's fast and everybody knows it... I also uploaded my program here just in case anybody is interested in playing with it: http://tinyurl.com/8nr2y Cheers! Stefan
43. Re: Sunes vs (O)LL
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 01:10:34 -0000

Oh, I forgot: if someone could come up with some simple rules to
actually use this as efficiently as the program showed is possible (i.
e. how to know which sune to apply and where in order to minimize the
number of sunes needed) then that would be great :-). So far I find it
interesting in theory but it would be cool to have it useful in
practice. For "COLL with up to 2 sunes" it's easy, if it's not solved
already or doable with a single sune then you just need to create a
case with three badly oriented corners, which is not hard. And the
number of cases there are of course much smaller so you can just learn
all of them. But finding out how to only flip four edges with 3 sunes
took me a bit of time and I'd like to be able to see it instantly...

Cheers!
Stefan






44. Cleaning out the cube

it early this year. It took ages. I'm surprised how much gunk had built
up inside! I've just re-lubed it too, so now it's feeling niiice. :)

I was just wondering how often other people take their cubes apart and
clean them?

Jasmine

46. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cleaning out the cube
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 20:38:15 -0800

I don't cube like I used to, but generally I try to clean my cubes
before a competition. Not sure if I'm going to get around to doing
that for San Francisco. I definitely had Dan Lo and Shelley in my room
and we lubed up cubes assembly line style outside while polluting the
small campus of Caltech with silicone fumes.

If you use one cube and you cube a lot, maybe once every month or two?
The thing I don't like is relubing a cube without replacing the
stickers, but I guess eventually the stuff comes off the cube. (and
onto your HANDS)

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

48. Re: Cleaning out the cube
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 08:52:23 -0000

Hello Everyone I usually wash my cubies in soapy water and then clean them w/ paper towels. Then spray silicone and reassemble. I know that it's unnecessary, but I probably do this twice a month. Sometimes once a week. The whole process is similar to changing the oil in a car. New lubricant, for moving mechanical parts. Jason --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jasmine Lee" <speedcuber@f...> wrote: > > Tonight I cleaned out my best speedcube for the first time since I got > it early this year. 49. Re: [Speed cubing group] 42 Cube Marathon
From: "Anders Larsson" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 11:47:20 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Similarly to the "no inspection" records I fear that some might always > start with certain cube orientations (e.g. scrambler puts white center > always on bottom) while others don't. Would be good (in both > categories) to have a rule so that everybody does the same. At the Swedish Cube Day 2005 (http://www.speedcubing.com/events/swedishcubeday2005.html), the orientation of the cube was scrambled (using a dice) in the no- inspection event. It should be easy to include cube orientation scrambling into the official scrambling programme. /Anders
50. Re: Petrus method
From: "Johannes Laire" <johannes.laire@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 14:00:39 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "washyourmonkey" <washyourmonkey@y...> wrote: > > is there anyone else out there there that uses the petrus method that > could give me some pointers that might help me break the 30 limit. im > curently doing low to mid 30's and just about every vid ive seen is > someone using fridrich. > > oh and are there any good timer apps for linux or any at all for that > matter? > I use the Petrus method and average 22-24 seconds with it. I've got several sub-20 averages and sub-15 times, too... I don't know if these advice help, but let's hope so: 1. Practice a lot doing the 2x2x2-box, you should try to do it in less than 8 moves. I guess I average something like 6 moves, but I'm not sure. 2. During the inspection time, you should be able to plan out a bit father than the 2x2x2, at least you should know which 2x2x3 you are going to build. Also practicing to do the whole 2x2x3-block blindfolded helps. 3. Don't always choose the fastest way to flip the edges in step 3. I, for example, combine steps 3 and 4a quite often. 4. Learn some algs for the last pair, though this is not necessary. 5. For the LL, I highly recommend using OLL and PLL. At least I find it better than COLL and PLL. 6. Practice going for fewest moves, you may find useful shortcuts or other tricks. - Johannes
51. HORSE
From: "thomkirjava" <snkenjoi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 15:07:13 -0000

I was just playing THPS4 and thought it'd be fun to apply it to cubing.

Here's how it works;

Basically, the aim of the game is to make the other person get all the
letters and be out. The letters are usually HORSE.

Firstly, You both scramble the same scramble, the person who goes
first sets a time and the next person has to beat it, otherwise they
get a letter. If the second person beats it, they both scramble again
with the same scramble and have to set a faster time then the second
person's. This carries on in a similar fashion until someone gets a
letter.

Then, the person who didn't get a letter goes first next time (this
time you use a new scramble). and you carry on in this fashion until
someone becomes a horse :P

You can play with different words, too. (CUBE :) )

~Thom

Remind me to add this to the wiki later..

From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>

wanted to know if there are any fellow cubers out here who are also
interested in this. Dont worry, its not always illegal...only when u
crack commercial softwares is it considered illegal.

It would be great if a fellow cuber also turns out to be a reverser, i
would love to talk with him/her :)

Also on other note, how many people here are into hardcore windows
programming? I mean C programming with the api's and stuff? I would
like to have a chat with u too if u do some windows programming.

Still, Happy cubing,
Sachin.


53. Re: Sunes vs (O)LL
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 18:22:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Oh, I forgot: if someone could come up with some simple rules to > actually use this as efficiently as the program showed is possible (i. > e. how to know which sune to apply and where in order to minimize the > number of sunes needed) then that would be great :-). So far I find it > interesting in theory but it would be cool to have it useful in > practice. For "COLL with up to 2 sunes" it's easy, if it's not solved > already or doable with a single sune then you just need to create a > case with three badly oriented corners, which is not hard. And the > number of cases there are of course much smaller so you can just learn > all of them. But finding out how to only flip four edges with 3 sunes > took me a bit of time and I'd like to be able to see it instantly... > > Cheers! > Stefan > Hi Stefan, This is how I see them: Definitions for this page: CUbe rotations QU = y sune: R U R' U R U2 R' reverse sune: R U2 R' U' R U' R' LH (left handed) sune: L' U' L U' L' U2 L reverse LH sune: L' U2 L U L' U L ** Symetrical position may be solved as mirror images. Here are my nicknames for the LL corner orientations and how to apply sunes. All Up: All the corners are upright. No sune needed. Three Down: Three corners are rotated clockwise or counterclockwise. Counterclockwise: Upright corner on FL: sune. CLockwise: Upright corner on BR: reverse sune. Headlights: Two corners are upright, two are rotated to face the same direction, like headlights on a car. Headlights face you: sune QU reverse sune. or sune QU2 LH sune. Sidelights: Two corners are upright, two are rotated to face away from each other. many different ways to do this Upright corners on the right, sune then left handed sune. or sune QU' reverse sune. or Upright corners in front: reverse sune QU sune. or reverse sune QU2 LH reverse sune. Oddlights: Two non-adjacent corners are upright, the other two are rotated. Right Rear is rotated counterclockwise and Left Front is rotated clockwise: sune QU2 reverse sune. Wheels: All four corners are rotated, two pairs face away from each other, like wheels on a car. The car is facing you the "Wheels" facing left and right: Sune twice. The car is facing left the "Wheels" facing front and back: Reverse sune twice. Barrow: All four corners are rotated, two face away from each other like wheels on the front of a wheel barrow, and two face the same direction like handles on a wheel barrow. The handles are in the back: sune QU sune. The handles are to the left: reverse sune LH sune. Put simply. (Once you know the names of the orientations) Sunes, done right handed or left handed, forwards or reversed, change a solved last level into the One Up Three Down orientation. In each case where two sunes are needed, after the first sune is applied you are left with the One Up Three Down orientation. There are 5 orientations needing two sunes - Headlights, Sidelights, Oddlights, Wheels, and Barrow. Application of first sune, R U R' U R U2 R': Headlights face you. Sidelights: Upright corners on the right. Oddlights: Right Rear is rotated counterclockwise and Left Front is rotated clockwise. Wheels: The car is facing you as if the "Wheels" are facing left and right. Barrow: The handles are in the back. Cheers, David J
54. Re: Sunes vs (O)LL
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 18:34:30 -0000

I am pretty sure that he meant he was looking for somebody to come up for rules for the non-COLL cases. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Oh, I forgot: if someone could come up with some simple rules to > > actually use this as efficiently as the program showed is possible (i. > > e. how to know which sune to apply and where in order to minimize the > > number of sunes needed) then that would be great :-). So far I find it > > interesting in theory but it would be cool to have it useful in > > practice. For "COLL with up to 2 sunes" it's easy, if it's not solved > > already or doable with a single sune then you just need to create a > > case with three badly oriented corners, which is not hard. And the > > number of cases there are of course much smaller so you can just learn > > all of them. But finding out how to only flip four edges with 3 sunes > > took me a bit of time and I'd like to be able to see it instantly... > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > Hi Stefan, > > This is how I see them: > > Definitions for this page: > CUbe rotations QU = y > sune: R U R' U R U2 R' > reverse sune: R U2 R' U' R U' R' > LH (left handed) sune: L' U' L U' L' U2 L > reverse LH sune: L' U2 L U L' U L > ** > Symetrical position may be solved as mirror images. > > Here are my nicknames for the LL corner orientations and how to apply > sunes. > > All Up: All the corners are upright. > No sune needed. > > Three Down: Three corners are rotated clockwise or counterclockwise. > Counterclockwise: Upright corner on FL: sune. > CLockwise: Upright corner on BR: reverse sune. > > Headlights: Two corners are upright, two are rotated to face the same > direction, like headlights on a car. > Headlights face you: sune QU reverse sune. > or sune QU2 LH sune. > > Sidelights: Two corners are upright, two are rotated to face away from > each other. > many different ways to do this > Upright corners on the right, sune then left handed sune. > or sune QU' reverse sune. > or > Upright corners in front: reverse sune QU sune. > or reverse sune QU2 LH reverse sune. > > Oddlights: Two non-adjacent corners are upright, the other two are > rotated. > Right Rear is rotated counterclockwise and Left Front is rotated > clockwise: sune QU2 reverse sune. > > Wheels: All four corners are rotated, two pairs face away from each > other, like wheels on a car. > The car is facing you the "Wheels" facing left and right: Sune twice. > The car is facing left the "Wheels" facing front and back: Reverse > sune twice. > > Barrow: All four corners are rotated, two face away from each other > like wheels on the front of a wheel barrow, and two face the same > direction like handles on a wheel barrow. > The handles are in the back: sune QU sune. > The handles are to the left: reverse sune LH sune. > > Put simply. (Once you know the names of the orientations) > > Sunes, done right handed or left handed, forwards or reversed, change > a solved last level into the One Up Three Down orientation. In each > case where two sunes are needed, after the first sune is applied you > are left with the One Up Three Down orientation. > > There are 5 orientations needing two sunes - Headlights, Sidelights, > Oddlights, Wheels, and Barrow. > > Application of first sune, R U R' U R U2 R': > > Headlights face you. > > Sidelights: Upright corners on the right. > > Oddlights: Right Rear is rotated counterclockwise and Left Front is > rotated clockwise. > > Wheels: The car is facing you as if the "Wheels" are facing left and > right. > > Barrow: The handles are in the back. > > Cheers, > > David J >
55. Re: Sunes vs (O)LL
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 18:40:34 -0000

Very interesting and helpful post. thanks! --Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Oh, I forgot: if someone could come up with some simple rules to > > actually use this as efficiently as the program showed is possible (i. > > e. how to know which sune to apply and where in order to minimize the > > number of sunes needed) then that would be great :-). So far I find it > > interesting in theory but it would be cool to have it useful in > > practice. For "COLL with up to 2 sunes" it's easy, if it's not solved > > already or doable with a single sune then you just need to create a > > case with three badly oriented corners, which is not hard. And the > > number of cases there are of course much smaller so you can just learn > > all of them. But finding out how to only flip four edges with 3 sunes > > took me a bit of time and I'd like to be able to see it instantly... > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > Hi Stefan, > > This is how I see them: > > Definitions for this page: > CUbe rotations QU = y > sune: R U R' U R U2 R' > reverse sune: R U2 R' U' R U' R' > LH (left handed) sune: L' U' L U' L' U2 L > reverse LH sune: L' U2 L U L' U L > ** > Symetrical position may be solved as mirror images. > > Here are my nicknames for the LL corner orientations and how to apply > sunes. > > All Up: All the corners are upright. > No sune needed. > > Three Down: Three corners are rotated clockwise or counterclockwise. > Counterclockwise: Upright corner on FL: sune. > CLockwise: Upright corner on BR: reverse sune. > > Headlights: Two corners are upright, two are rotated to face the same > direction, like headlights on a car. > Headlights face you: sune QU reverse sune. > or sune QU2 LH sune. > > Sidelights: Two corners are upright, two are rotated to face away from > each other. > many different ways to do this > Upright corners on the right, sune then left handed sune. > or sune QU' reverse sune. > or > Upright corners in front: reverse sune QU sune. > or reverse sune QU2 LH reverse sune. > > Oddlights: Two non-adjacent corners are upright, the other two are > rotated. > Right Rear is rotated counterclockwise and Left Front is rotated > clockwise: sune QU2 reverse sune. > > Wheels: All four corners are rotated, two pairs face away from each > other, like wheels on a car. > The car is facing you the "Wheels" facing left and right: Sune twice. > The car is facing left the "Wheels" facing front and back: Reverse > sune twice. > > Barrow: All four corners are rotated, two face away from each other > like wheels on the front of a wheel barrow, and two face the same > direction like handles on a wheel barrow. > The handles are in the back: sune QU sune. > The handles are to the left: reverse sune LH sune. > > Put simply. (Once you know the names of the orientations) > > Sunes, done right handed or left handed, forwards or reversed, change > a solved last level into the One Up Three Down orientation. In each > case where two sunes are needed, after the first sune is applied you > are left with the One Up Three Down orientation. > > There are 5 orientations needing two sunes - Headlights, Sidelights, > Oddlights, Wheels, and Barrow. > > Application of first sune, R U R' U R U2 R': > > Headlights face you. > > Sidelights: Upright corners on the right. > > Oddlights: Right Rear is rotated counterclockwise and Left Front is > rotated clockwise. > > Wheels: The car is facing you as if the "Wheels" are facing left and > right. > > Barrow: The handles are in the back. > > Cheers, > > David J >

58. Fuji TV Media Request <Rubik's Cube>
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 22 Dec 2005 21:24:33 -0000

If anybody is interested, let me know. He is looking for 4-6 more
people. He wants to know by Friday. My e-mail address is
bob[at]cubewhiz[dot]com.

~ Bob

--- Original Message ---
Hi Bob

This is Sakura from Fuji TV.
Currently I am producing upcoming segment for our weekly live news
show which will be air on 12/27 (TUE) from Time Warner Center at
Columbus Circle (60th & Columbus Ave). It is going to be our last
episode for 2005 and we are introducing the best of 2005. I learned
that you organize the event which happened this month at the Rutgers
University, and I am wondering if you know some competitors.
To complete our segment, we would like to have some competitors as
professionals of Rubik's Cube.

We would like to introduce the revival of rubik's cube this year,
especially talk about the championship in Florida. We are looking
forward to having a competitor from the world championship also.

-We need you on 12/27(TUE) from 4pm-6pm
-We would like you to solve the Rubik's cube

It is a very short notice, but please understand that it took us for a
while to reach you. Introducing you will be the highlight of our show,
and we Do hope that your fellows will be able to participate our show.
We will prepare you transportation in the case of strike. We would
like to accommodate as much as possible to make this happen, please
let us know if we can do anything for you. We have a great viewer ship
in Japan and it is going to be a live news show like Good Morning
America. You will be able to watch the channel on channel 63. also.
Please let us know the possibility. Since I am on the deadline, I
appreciate your response. I will try to reach you later today.

Thank you very much for your attention to this matter. Below, I will
attach the program information.
Sincerely,


Fuji TV
Sakura Nakamura
Assistant Director

Phone: 212-702-0643
E-Mail: mezamashi@...
Address:150 E52nd 34th Floor. New York, NY, 10022




---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Fuji Television & Mezamashi TV (morning news show)

We have been working on a live segment for our morning news program titled
Mezamashi TV (Wake-up TV) for the last 10 years. This program is
similar in
scale and format to NBC's Today's Show and ABC's Good Morning America."
Over 20 million Japanese wake-up to the news, information and
entertainment
of Mezamashi TV every morning, and we have produced over 700 various live
segments from New York. In this past summer, Jennifer Lopez and
Backstreet
Boys did live performance during the live Mezamashi TV in Tokyo.

Our company, Fujisankei Communication International, Inc., function as the
main international branch office of Fuji Television Network in Japan by
distributing and producing TV programs. Fuji Television Network is the
largest commercial broadcasting company in Japan, and our broadcast
network
delivers programming to over 98% of the Japanese population. We are based
in New York and broadcasts news and entertainment to over 80,000
viewers in
New York City area.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

62. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich & Cage method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Dec 2005 15:21:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi! > > That 'Arc de Triomphe' is so well known that i didn't bother to post > it yet. Even Stefan knows that one ;-) That's right, even I knew that ;-) Now here's a new task: F' R' S' D' F' M F D S R F is to L D M' B l F l' B' M D' L' what F' R S' D F' M F D' S R' F is to ?????????????????????????? In other words, 4-cycle corner/edge pairs again but this time every second corner comes from D instead of U. Any 4-cycle of these corner/edge pairs is ok. Find a short algorithm, don't use computer help. I have a hard time with it. Cheers! Stefan
63. Re: Sunes vs (O)LL
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Dec 2005 16:25:50 -0000

Hi Stefan, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > 9 cases need 3 sunes. > > One of these 9 is the OLL case where the corners are correct but all > four edges need to be flipped. Can you solve that with 3 sune > variants? Who needs three? I solved it with 2 sune variants, varied by adding slice moves. b R U R' U R U2 R' U b' QU' Rr U2 R' U' R U' R'r' U' Regards, David J > > If you don't mirror but only invert and/or setup M', then this OLL > case is the only one that needs four sunes, so this is somewhat the > "hardest case" :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan >

DJ --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Very interesting and helpful post. thanks! > --Kirk > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: [snip] > > Hi Stefan, > > > > This is how I see them: > > > > Definitions for this page: > > CUbe rotations QU = y > > sune: R U R' U R U2 R' > > reverse sune: R U2 R' U' R U' R' > > LH (left handed) sune: L' U' L U' L' U2 L > > reverse LH sune: L' U2 L U L' U L > > ** > > Symetrical position may be solved as mirror images. > > > > Here are my nicknames for the LL corner orientations and how to > apply > > sunes. > > > > All Up: All the corners are upright. > > No sune needed. > > > > Three Down: Three corners are rotated clockwise or > counterclockwise. > > Counterclockwise: Upright corner on FL: sune. > > CLockwise: Upright corner on BR: reverse sune. > > > > Headlights: Two corners are upright, two are rotated to face the > same > > direction, like headlights on a car. > > Headlights face you: sune QU reverse sune. > > or sune QU2 LH sune. > > > > Sidelights: Two corners are upright, two are rotated to face away > from > > each other. > > many different ways to do this > > Upright corners on the right, sune then left handed sune. > > or sune QU' reverse sune. > > or > > Upright corners in front: reverse sune QU sune. > > or reverse sune QU2 LH reverse sune. > > > > Oddlights: Two non-adjacent corners are upright, the other two are > > rotated. > > Right Rear is rotated counterclockwise and Left Front is rotated > > clockwise: sune QU2 reverse sune. > > > > Wheels: All four corners are rotated, two pairs face away from > each > > other, like wheels on a car. > > The car is facing you the "Wheels" facing left and right: Sune > twice. > > The car is facing left the "Wheels" facing front and back: Reverse > > sune twice. > > > > Barrow: All four corners are rotated, two face away from each other > > like wheels on the front of a wheel barrow, and two face the same > > direction like handles on a wheel barrow. > > The handles are in the back: sune QU sune. > > The handles are to the left: reverse sune LH sune. > > > > Put simply. (Once you know the names of the orientations) > > > > Sunes, done right handed or left handed, forwards or reversed, > change > > a solved last level into the One Up Three Down orientation. In each > > case where two sunes are needed, after the first sune is applied > you > > are left with the One Up Three Down orientation. > > > > There are 5 orientations needing two sunes - Headlights, > Sidelights, > > Oddlights, Wheels, and Barrow. > > > > Application of first sune, R U R' U R U2 R': > > > > Headlights face you. > > > > Sidelights: Upright corners on the right. > > > > Oddlights: Right Rear is rotated counterclockwise and Left Front > is > > rotated clockwise. > > > > Wheels: The car is facing you as if the "Wheels" are facing left > and > > right. > > > > Barrow: The handles are in the back. > > > > Cheers, > > > > David J > > >
