385. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Explaining the math behind cubing to kids
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 14:48:32 -0800

I think one of the most important thing to point out to non cubers is that the cube is made up of the smaller "cubies" if you will. Alot of people think that each sticker can be moved individually. Another good one is the difference between orientation and permutation. Then, if you want to be really ambitious, you can try to explain commutators, but I've never found a good way to explain it in speech form, I always have to sit down and show someone. And you have to give them a website that they can visit to learn more about the cube. Just a couple of ideas, -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.net On 12/28/05, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@gmx.de> wrote: > > You could calculate how much of your lifetime you've already wasted > for cubing :-). And then argue that you haven't wasted enough because > your goal is to reach every possible state. Imagine... > > - you could twist (the corner tips) with the speed of light > - you'd twist your whole life (assume 100 years) > - never visit a state twice so you don't waste time > > How much of the cube space would you visit? If I didn't make a > mistake, it's about 35.7% which I think is a very nice number cause > it's large enough to be graspable and doesn't reach 100%. > > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey guys, > > > > Someone asked me to do a demonstration of the cube for some kids, > and > > tell some nice things about it... The kids are about 11-12 years > old. > > Does anyone have good ideas about what I should tell them? And, more > > important: how I should tell it to them, so they would understand? > > > > Thanks! > > > > Joël. > > > > > > > > ------------------------------ > YAHOO! 387. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 2006 Regulation Revisions
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 14:51:45 -0800

I remember at the 2004 us nationals it was quarter turn. I'm sure there is a reason for this, but I personally disagree (never happened to me, I just have different views). They way I think about it is that if we are going to scramble in the half turn metric, then this rule should also be applied in the half turn metric. That's all, -Evan Until next time, Happy Cubing http://www.deepcube.net On 12/28/05, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...> wrote: > > This was an issue this year. > I think it should be clarified for next year too > (I have to check the WCA forum, maybe it's already been discussed there) > Gilles. > > 2005/12/28, Anssi Vanhala <mahtianssi@...>: > > "If a side is misaligned by more than the above criteria, then that > > side is considered one turn away. If a cube is one turn from > > completion, 2 seconds will be added to the solve time. In all other > > cases, the solve is disqualified." > > QTM or HTM? > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" > > <ron@s...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi friends, > > > > > > I think everything has been said now about extra attempt for pops. > > Thank you > > > all for your input. > > > There is still a majority favoring no extra attempts for pops, > > even for the > > > bigger cubes. In return these cubers get 5 instead of 3 attempts. > > > Let us see what 2006 brings. > > > > > > Stefan, for WC2003 there were no clear regulations about the > > cubing itself. > > > Actually there were a few people (even finalists) getting extra > > attempts for > > > having the last face not correctly aligned. On one occasion there > > was > > > someone getting two extra attempts for the same cube. And each of > > the three > > > scrambles was the same! There was also no limit for pops, so there > > was > > > someone who had 3 pops, and received 3 extra attempts. Another > > thing was > > > that the regulations were very personal, one judge would react > > differently > > > than another judge. > > > We should be happy now that we have good regulations. :-) > > > > > > About the twisted center corner of Masayuki Akimoto. > > > It is my mistake that the twisted center corner for Masayuki for > > his 5x5x5 > > > attempt was not allowed. > > > The judge came to me together with Masayuki, and asked me whether > > it was > > > allowed or not. Even Masayuki said that he would not have a > > problem if it > > > were not allowed. > > > I was in doubt at that moment, so I should have checked the > > regulations. > > > The regulations 2005 say: > > > " > > > All pieces of the puzzle must be ATTACHED to the puzzle for it to > > be solved. > > > If a piece of the puzzle is EJECTED as the puzzle is placed down > > but it is > > > otherwise solved, then the puzzle is not considered to be in a > > solved state. > > > " > > > > > > The piece was attached, but ejected and not in solved position. > > Reading back > > > now I think it should have been allowed. > > > I am glad in the end it did not make much of a difference. > > Although I am not > > > sure whether it was Masayuki's fastest time of the competition and > > thus a > > > Japanese record. > > > > > > My mistake. Sorry. Lesson learnt. > > > > > > About the center corner of 5x5x5 being broken. > > > The regulations 2005 say: > > > "If a non functional part of a puzzle is defect/ejected and the > > puzzle is > > > still unambiguously in a solved state, then the puzzle is > > considered solved, > > > under discretion of the judge." > > > In this case you could consider the flat part of the center corner > > to be a > > > non functional part, because the inner part of the center is still > > in place. > > > If the puzzle is unambiguously in a solved state, so only one of > > the center > > > corners with this problem, then the puzzle should be considered > > solved. > > > > > > Looking forward to more competitions in 2006 in more countries, > > with even > > > more fun. > > > > > > Have fun, > > > > > > Ron > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > > From: Per Kristen Fredlund > > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > > Sent: Tuesday, December 27, 2005 6:36 PM > > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 2006 Regulation Revisions > > > > > > > > > Hi ! > > > > > > That's more evidence to keep the current rule, allowing ONE pop. It > > > really is no problem timewise to allow a few ppl one more solve due > > > to (accidental) pop. And ppl can cube faster more relaxed, not > > > having to worry too much about pops. Anyway, i feel this topic > > > is "out-debated". What happens will happen. Can I take on your challenge and also switch every time? I'd like that :) /Gustav Tyson Mao skrev: >No, I'm not pointing to you. Especially the >people who claim that the probability is even at 1/2 and 1/2. > >At the end of this, I'll even give back the money that you lost if you >concede that the probability is indeed 1/3 and 2/3. Look, there's no >money lost here. I'm giving people who believe that the probability is >1/2 and 1/2 a risk free opportunity to prove themselves, and make a >little money while they're at it if they're correct. > >Tyson Mao >MSC #631 >California Institute of Technology > >On Dec 28, 2005, at 2:25 PM, Gustav Fredell wrote: > > > >>Hey, >> >>You're not pointing on me when you say "you", do you? I'm all with you >>(and pretty much the rest of the world) on this. I now my statistics >>and probabilities well. University well :) >> >>/Gustav >> >>Tyson Mao skrev: >> >> >> >>>It's a hilarious idea, but with the sad undertone that this discussion >>>has even gone this far. The probability of winning the game if you >>>switch the door is 2/3. We make several assumptions: >>> >>>No one is "out to get you." >>>The host offers you the switch every single time. >>>The host knows which door the prize is behind. >>>Psychics are full of crap. >>> >>>Just play the game yourself. This "law of large numbers" not applying >>>is false. Probability doesn't mean that something will or won't >>>happen, it's how often it should happen. If we carry out an infinite >>>number of tests, well, and I think it's called the central limit >>>theorem but I'm not certain, the probabilities should even out to >>>about >>>2/3 and 1/3. If you do it 1000 times, the probability will generally >>>come out to 2/3 and 1/3, but it won't be exact, and it could come out >>>weird... you could win 1000 times in a row. At the same time, I could >>>tunnel through a brick wall. That's probability. >>> >>>Play the game yourself. Work out the probability, read the actual >>>text >>>of the problem as stated on that website, and if we can agree on the >>>text of the problem, and the manner of which the game is played, there >>>is no doubt that probability is 2/3 and 1/3. There is no +epsilon or >>>-epsilon because for the sake of a math problem, no one is right >>>handed >>>or left handed. No one has a preference, pure randomness is possible. >>> >>>Honestly, if you were playing the game, would you actually stay with >>>the door you chose because you believe the probability of you winning >>>is 1/2? If so, you deserve to lose that car. In fact, why don't we >>>do >>>this. I'll be the host of this game and I'll give you 100 trials. >>>The >>>prize behind the door in my game will be $5 USD. >>> >>>Then, you be the host, and you give me 100 trials. The prize behind >>>the door in your game is $4 USD. I'll switch the door every time, and >>>you keep your door every time. If the probability is 1/2, I think you >>>stand to make $50 USD in this game. Who's up for it? >>> >>>I'm putting up money here. Those who are convinced of their answer >>>should step up. I'm convinced of my answer, and I'm putting my money >>>where my mouth is. >>> >>>Tyson Mao >>>MSC #631 >>>California Institute of Technology >>> >>>On Dec 28, 2005, at 1:00 PM, Gustav Fredell wrote: >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>>>Thats a hilarious idea. Go Tyson! I just wish I could be there. I >>>>have >>>>a >>>>certain tactic I'm sure works, unless you pull the Lindsey Lohan card >>>>mentioned by Marco. >>>> >>>>/Gustav >>>> >>>>Tyson Mao skrev: >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>> >>>>>I'm going to set up this game, but instead of a car as a prize, as >>>>>I'm >>>>>obviously not that wealthy, I'll give away free cubes. We'll do >>>>>this >>>>>in San Francisco during the break and we'll just call up random >>>>>members >>>>>of the audience who are there spectating the competition. If I have >>>>>enough cubes, I'll do it 10 times. >>>>> >>>>>Tyson Mao >>>>>MSC #631 >>>>>California Institute of Technology >>>>> >>>>>On Dec 28, 2005, at 12:46 PM, Rune Wesstrï¿½m wrote: >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> >>>>> >>>>>>"Good thinking Stefan!" ? He is contradicting himself when saying: >>>>>>"you can gain some knowledge this way and be more sure that >>>>>>changing >>>>>>would be better...but... the probability stays at 2/3". But if we >>>>>>had >>>>>>a probability of 2/3 whithout this knowledge and then bettered it, >>>>>>how >>>>>>can we still stay at 2/3? He is discussing the a priori >>>>>>probabilities >>>>>>before the first choise, *I* am discussing the probabilities before >>>>>>the second choice, that is, when the host has opened one door. >>>>>>There >>>>>>is some concensus here that the probabilities are 1/3 or 2/3. But >>>>>>if >>>>>>we accept the theoretical assumtion (Pochmann apparently does) that >>>>>>the host has an "easy" door and a "difficult" door and he chooses >>>>>>the >>>>>>first with a probability of 1/2 + epsilon and the second with a >>>>>>probability 1/2 - epsilon (epsilon not 0), the result will be >>>>>>another. >>>>>>Ask mister Pochmann to calculate the probabilities for you. Mister >>>>>>Bayes may help him. >>>>>>R >>>>>>----- Original Message ----- >>>>>>From: "pjgat09" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> >>>>>>To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> >>>>>>Sent: Wednesday, December 28, 2005 5:41 PM >>>>>>Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors... >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>>Thats the best way I have heard it put for this entire dicussion. >>>>>>Good >>>>>>thinking Stefan! >>>>>> >>>>>>Peter Greenwood >>>>>> >>>>>>--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" >>>>>><pochmann@g...> wrote: >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>>>This doesn't make the argument wrong. 389. [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 22:54:32 -0000

Ok, I'm done. With this idea of gaining extra information (i.e. not like in the original pure probability riddle) I'm not sure we should talk about *the* probability that changing or keeping your door wins a certain fraction of all cases. That's because now it depends on your strategy. For simplicity, let's consider my extreme hint example again where you *know* where the car is before your second decision. The probability for something is roughly speaking the good events divided by all events. Now if your strategy is "keep if and only if I was right" then you always win. That is, all your "change" decisions and all your "keep" decisions will win. Instead of 2/3 and 1/3 we now have 3/3 and 3/3. However, if your strategy is "keep if and only if I was wrong" then we drop to 0/3 and 0/3. So it depends on your strategy and thus speaking about *the* probability for keep/change doesn't make much sense, at least not directly. I guess this term could make sense if you define it over *all strategies*, and then it might be 2/3 and 1/3 again, but I won't dare to claim that cause now it's getting too complicated :-) If we talk about keep/change as strategies, short for "I'll always keep my door" (or "change"), then 2/3 and 1/3 is correct. It's also correct if your choice is random. Or if you always alternate between keep/change (unless the correct door alternates accordingly). Or other constructions that keep the 2/3 vs 1/3 probabilities for keep vs change. But inside other strategies, the probabilities can be very very different. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@...m, Rune Wesström <rune. > wesstrom@h...> wrote: > > > > "Good thinking Stefan!" ? He is contradicting himself when saying: > "you can gain some knowledge this way and be more sure that changing > would be better...but... the probability stays at 2/3". But if we had > a probability of 2/3 whithout this knowledge and then bettered it, how > can we still stay at 2/3? > > > Hehe, you better don't remove the important parts of the quote :-). I > was talking about two different things. I said: > > > > Yes, you can gain some knowledge > > > this way and be more sure that changing would be better. But it > > > doesn't make you win more often when changing. The probability for > > > that stays at 2/3. > > The probability that "change" wins the car stays at 2/3 and the > probability for "keep" stays at 1/3. The extra knowledge doesn't help > to make these strategies any better, "keep" wins if and only if your > initial choice was correct (1/3) and "change" wins if and only if it > was wrong (2/3). > > What you *can* do with this extra knowledge is make up a *better > strategy* than those two. In my extreme example where you get to see > the car, a good strategy would be "keep my door if and only if it > contains the car". This *new* strategy wins the car 100% of the time. > > Now what about the situation you described? The game is the same but > you get extra information from the behaviour of the host. Can you use > it to make up a new strategy? > > Hmmmmm.... actually I just noticed something. Gotta think about it, > will be back when I'm done with that. But I'm gonna submit the above > now anyway. > > Cheers! > Stefan >

391. Re: Centers MOD
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 23:00:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, a_ooms75 <no_reply@y... > wrote: > > i solve the centers up to when i see that 3 centers needs to be > placed. Can you be more precise what you mean here? For me it sounds like you do my step 1, then during step 2 you only solve one center piece of each color into the l slice (because then 3 still need to be placed). But that seems a bit early... Stefan
392. Re: Centers MOD
From: a_ooms75 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 23:10:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, a_ooms75 <no_reply@y... > > wrote: > > > > i solve the centers up to when i see that 3 centers needs to be > > placed. > > Can you be more precise what you mean here? For me it sounds like you > do my step 1, then during step 2 you only solve one center piece of > each color into the l slice (because then 3 still need to be placed). > But that seems a bit early... > > Stefan > example: Perform on a solved cube: (Rr)' F' (Rr) (Bb)' R' (Bb) (Ff) R (Ff') Now your left with 3 peaces of centers to be done. AO
393. Re: Centers MOD
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 23:19:30 -0000

Ok ok, forget my previous question. Now I understand that you meant three center pieces overall to be shot down. Now some other questions... :-) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, a_ooms75 <no_reply@y... > wrote: > > 1th step: > Look at UB edges then first im looking for UBr and place that in UFl > and then UFr to the FDl and do (Rr)' F (Rr) > Then 2 edge pairs are connected. > and 2 centers to go. This is clear. > 2nd step: > Looking at UB the first look at UBl and place the temporay in URb > then look at UBr place that in UFl and then UFr to the FDl then FDr > to the URf > then i do L to set URb in place on FLu Then do (Rr)' F (Rr) > Then 4 edge pairs are connected > and 1 center to go This confuses me... I think you're trying to somehow keep the edge pairs you built in the 1st step intact, is that right? Actually a while ago I had this idea of building edges together with centers, but I gave up on it real quick because I kept destroying my edge pairs, or it was too much work to keep them intact. Looks like I should try again... > 3rd step: > repeat step 2 > Then 4 edge pairs are connected > and centers done. Is this a type or are really only 4 pairs connected, not 6? > and i have been trying this also with just step 1 repeated 3 time's > then 6 edges are done Can you point out more how your above method differs from just doing step 1 three times? Btw, how have you been connecting edges so far? I use to build two pairs at a time, using algs like r' U' R U r. Cheers! Stefan
394. [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 23:37:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > In fact, why don't we do > this. I'll be the host of this game and I'll give you 100 trials. The > prize behind the door in my game will be $5 USD. > > Then, you be the host, and you give me 100 trials. The prize behind > the door in your game is $4 USD. I'll switch the door every time, and > you keep your door every time. If the probability is 1/2, I think you > stand to make $50 USD in this game. Who's up for it? For some reason too difficult to explain here (but you can read it in the book of Baltalan and Leeves) I don't think this is fair. We must play at the same time. For this, I suggest the following procedure (it's basically the same game but initially with two players): We need a third person who'll be the host and you give him your $5 and I give him my $4. He places the $9 behind one of three doors. We both choose a door. If it's the same we try again until we choose different ones. Then, only one of us can continue the game. The host opens an empty door, either yours or mine. The one who had this door is out, the other can choose to keep his door or change to the third door (which none of us chose). If the wrong door is chosen, we try again (playing for the same $9). We do this 10 times and you always switch and I always keep. Ok? Cheers! Stefan
395. Error in provided Algorithms
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: "Speedsolving Group" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 19:42:43 -0400

Hey All,


I am currently learning the algorithms (BigCubes.com) for solving the last Edges for the Professor Cube, but came across a snag.

Two of the algs on the page are incorrect and I've also found that there are more than the nine cases provided on the page. I managed to solve the error in one of the algs (top row third from left) although the other algorithm is too complex for me.

Can anyone solve the case correcting the provided algorithm: second row third from the left?
And does anyone know how many cases there are? I've come across 11 so far (2 more than the site)

This is the direct link to the above discussed page:
http://www.bigcubes.com/5x5x5/lastedges.html

Thanks Dwayne

I use to build two > pairs at a time, using algs like r' U' R U r. yes the 2 edge method i use normale > > Cheers! > Stefan > all this can be done with (Ll) F' (Ll)' but then its all mirrored :) greets AO

398. Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 23:56:18 -0000

Hi Tyson, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > Time difference? So if I understand you correctly, humans have a > certain ESP which is also depended on the time variation in the > decisions? No. If the computer takes longer to ask you if you want to switch after you chose correctly this could be perceived, consciously or unconsciously, and affect your choice. > So far, the latest arguments have all been that humans are able to > influence things that are random and have an ability to get the 'right' > answer when they don't know any information regarding the answer at > all. Can you produce an honest refutation of the Rhine experiments? You seem to guarantee that everyone will be wrong 2/3rds of the time. There is no guarantee. > However, can you agree that a computer playing the game will win > 2/3 of the time if the computer switches the door every time? I think it's possible. Are you using the same "random number" generator for both sides of the game? They could accidently line up and the computer contestent could choose correctly 100% of the time, and switching 100% of the time it would lose 100% of the time. I'm curious, what percentage of the time will the game be won if the computer contestant switches it's choice 2/3s of the time? Cheers, David J > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Dec 27, 2005, at 11:10 AM, d_j_salvia wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > >> > >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > >> <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > >>> > >>> As I wrote in response to Gustav, I did 100 trials with no switching > >>> and won 76 times. > >> > >> I think you overestimate our stupidity. > >> > >> Cheers! > >> Stefan > >> > > > > Stefan, > > > > If I thought you were stupid I would not put so much effort into > > explaining my thoughts on the matter. > > > > I did the experiment and reported the result. If the result does not > > coincide with your beliefs that is not my problem. > > > > If you did not check the program that you used for this test, to see > > it there was any time difference between processing a correct initial > > guess and processing an incorrect initial guess, then you cannot tell > > me for certain that you know that you got no feedback cues whatsoever. > > > > Did you check? > > > > Bye, > > > > David J > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

400. [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 00:08:55 -0000

Gustav, What you say is correct. You wrote, in part, > it simulates human choices very well < human choices, yes, a single human choice, no. It is well known that when the behavior of groups of humans may be predicted, the behavior of individuals may not be predicted on the same basis. Regards, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@s...> wrote: > > Your program is actually fine, and even though it's "only" a computer > simulation it simulates human choices very well in this instance. > > /Gustav > > Daniel Hayes skrev: > > >I'm not sure I follow what exactly you're saying. My goal was never > >to simulate human behavior in the game, but the effect of switching > >vs. not switching. Is there a flaw in the way I went about it? I'm > >always looking for programming tips :) > > > >-Daniel > > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > ><d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > > >>Hi Daniel, > >> > >>By removing the human element your computer program only shows that > >>the pseudo-"random number generator" you used works well within a > >>million expressions. It says nothing about a human making choices > >>within a single game. > >> > >>Cheers, > >> > >>David J > >> > >> > >> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >__________ NOD32 1.1340 (20051226) Information __________ > > > >This message was checked by NOD32 antivirus system. > >http://www.nod32.com > > > > > > > > > > >

406. Re: Silicon spray on the plane or in the suitcase ?
From: "Eric" <maier@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 00:54:05 -0000

Thanks Stefan, Weight is a term describing viscosity. The smaller the weithg number the lower the viscosity. The higher the weight the greater the viscosity. Just another unit of measure as far as I know. I'll get some higher weight lube and try it out. Thanks, Eric --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > The 50 is "too fluid". I haven't used it very often yet but I think it > drops out of the cube more easily, and I think it feels more "sticky". > Wet your hands with water, press them against each other and slide > them against each other. It actually makes it stiffer than when my > hands are dry. Silicone oil just makes the sliding easier (I believe.. > . I admit I never really tried that :-). Same with 50 vs 1000, the 50 > gives me a more sticky feeling I think. > > What exactly does the "weight" value describe? It's certainly not the > weight of the oil itself, my 1000 weighs about the same as my 50, > certainly not 20 times as much :-) > > Cheers! > STefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eric" <maier@d...> > wrote: > > > > Yes, viscosity / weight are the same idea. > > > > Never tried a heavier weight. What do you like better about it? > > > > Thanks, > > > > Eric > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > Does anyone know whether this has to do with the viscosity? And if > > > yes, what's the correspondence? > > > > > > I have two silicone oils, one with viscosity 50 and one with 1000 > > > (yes, the smallest and largest they had). The 50 is very fluid > whereas > > > the 1000 is like gel. I like the 1000 better. > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, christopher_pelley > > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > I noticed that for silicone oil (such as Shock Oil), there are > > > > different weights. Do you prefer the lighter or heaver weights? > > > > The > > > > hobby store I visited had 25, 55, and 80 weights available. > I've > > > also > > > > seen a 10-weight online. > > > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > One of the reasons silicone oil rules :-) > > > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

408. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 16:58:20 -0800

In order to appease Stefan, I propose we play the game this way: I put in $5, and you put in $4. The combined $9 is put behind one of the three doors (or cups, or whatever). I'll let you choose the door. You choose the door, someone reveals a door without the money (that's not the door you chose). If the $9 is behind the original door you chose, you keep the money. If it's behind the other door, I'll keep the money. We repeat this 100 times. I'm not arguing the probabilities of this game anymore. Here's the game. Do you want to play? If indeed the answer is 1/2, 1/2, then you'll win $50. If you have ESP and can perceive things, then you'll win money. I'm prepared to part with up to $500 for this game. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Dec 28, 2005, at 3:56 PM, d_j_salvia wrote: > Hi Tyson, > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> >> Time difference? So if I understand you correctly, humans have a >> certain ESP which is also depended on the time variation in the >> decisions? > > No. If the computer takes longer to ask you if you want to switch > after you chose correctly this could be perceived, consciously or > unconsciously, and affect your choice. > >> So far, the latest arguments have all been that humans are able to >> influence things that are random and have an ability to get the >> 'right' >> answer when they don't know any information regarding the answer at >> all. > > Can you produce an honest refutation of the Rhine experiments? > > You seem to guarantee that everyone will be wrong 2/3rds of the time. > There is no guarantee. > >> However, can you agree that a computer playing the game will win >> 2/3 of the time if the computer switches the door every time? > > I think it's possible. > Are you using the same "random number" generator for both sides of the > game? They could accidently line up and the computer contestent could > choose correctly 100% of the time, and switching 100% of the time it > would lose 100% of the time. > > I'm curious, what percentage of the time will the game be won if the > computer contestant switches it's choice 2/3s of the time? > > Cheers, > > David J > >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology >> >> On Dec 27, 2005, at 11:10 AM, d_j_salvia wrote: >> >>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" >>> <pochmann@g...> wrote: >>>> >>>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" >>>> <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: >>>>> >>>>> As I wrote in response to Gustav, I did 100 trials with no >>>>> switching >>>>> and won 76 times. >>>> >>>> I think you overestimate our stupidity. >>>> >>>> Cheers! >>>> Stefan >>>> >>> >>> Stefan, >>> >>> If I thought you were stupid I would not put so much effort into >>> explaining my thoughts on the matter. >>> >>> I did the experiment and reported the result. If the result does not >>> coincide with your beliefs that is not my problem. >>> >>> If you did not check the program that you used for this test, to see >>> it there was any time difference between processing a correct initial >>> guess and processing an incorrect initial guess, then you cannot tell >>> me for certain that you know that you got no feedback cues >>> whatsoever. >>> >>> Did you check? >>> >>> Bye, >>> >>> David J >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> Yahoo! 411. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 17:13:31 -0800

No, I don't guarantee that everyone who keeps the same door will be
wrong 2/3rds of the time. I know that if we carry this out to a large
number, such as 100, that it is pretty much guaranteed that they will
be wrong about 2/3rds of the time. That's what probability is.

The game will be won if the contestant switches doors 2/3rds of the
time is calculated by the following:

(1/3)(1/3) + (2/3)(2/3) = 5/9

The contestant will win 5 out of 9 times.

Bob's computer simulation shows that switching the door will win twice
as often as not switching the door. That's 2/3 and 1/3 probability. A
quick look a Bob's simulation shows, by calculation as I did earlier,
that the overall outcome of 1/2 switch and 1/2 not switching should be
1/2. His experiment confirms exactly what we were looking for.

I've already stated over and over again. If you believe that a person
will win 1/2 of the time by not switching, then play my game. I'll
even up the stakes if you want to make more money off of me.

I could give you arguments all day, but I'm not. It's simple, will you
play my game? Will you challenge my answer? Unless there is some
flawed mechanism of how I set up the game, prove to me that you're
right and earn your $50. You could buy 5 cubes with that money.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Dec 28, 2005, at 3:56 PM, d_j_salvia wrote:

> You seem to guarantee that everyone will be wrong 2/3rds of the time.
> There is no guarantee.
>
> I'm curious, what percentage of the time will the game be won if the
> computer contestant switches it's choice 2/3s of the time?

413. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 03:08:43 +0100

Just to argue a bit more in this thread (which is very silly) I have a couple of questions: Are you suggesting that I still have 1/3, 2/3 (any way) when choosing at random or always alternating between staying/switching? If you did that should read 1/2, 1/2. /Gustav Stefan Pochmann skrev: >Ok, I'm done. With this idea of gaining extra information (i.e. not >like in the original pure probability riddle) I'm not sure we should >talk about *the* probability that changing or keeping your door wins a >certain fraction of all cases. > >That's because now it depends on your strategy. For simplicity, let's >consider my extreme hint example again where you *know* where the car >is before your second decision. The probability for something is >roughly speaking the good events divided by all events. Now if your >strategy is "keep if and only if I was right" then you always win. >That is, all your "change" decisions and all your "keep" decisions >will win. Instead of 2/3 and 1/3 we now have 3/3 and 3/3. However, if >your strategy is "keep if and only if I was wrong" then we drop to 0/3 >and 0/3. > >So it depends on your strategy and thus speaking about *the* >probability for keep/change doesn't make much sense, at least not >directly. I guess this term could make sense if you define it over >*all strategies*, and then it might be 2/3 and 1/3 again, but I won't >dare to claim that cause now it's getting too complicated :-) > >If we talk about keep/change as strategies, short for "I'll always >keep my door" (or "change"), then 2/3 and 1/3 is correct. It's also >correct if your choice is random. Or if you always alternate between >keep/change (unless the correct door alternates accordingly). Or other >constructions that keep the 2/3 vs 1/3 probabilities for keep vs >change. But inside other strategies, the probabilities can be very >very different. > >Cheers! >Stefan > > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" ><pochmann@g...> wrote: > > >>--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Rune Wesstrï¿½m <rune. >>wesstrom@h...> wrote: >> >> >>>"Good thinking Stefan!" ? He is contradicting himself when saying: >>> >>> >>"you can gain some knowledge this way and be more sure that changing >>would be better...but... the probability stays at 2/3". But if we >> >> >had > > >>a probability of 2/3 whithout this knowledge and then bettered it, >> >> >how > > >>can we still stay at 2/3? >> >> >>Hehe, you better don't remove the important parts of the quote :-). >> >> >I > > >>was talking about two different things. I said: >> >> >> >>>>Yes, you can gain some knowledge >>>>this way and be more sure that changing would be better. But it >>>>doesn't make you win more often when changing. The probability >>>> >>>> >for > > >>>>that stays at 2/3. >>>> >>>> >>The probability that "change" wins the car stays at 2/3 and the >>probability for "keep" stays at 1/3. The extra knowledge doesn't >> >> >help > > >>to make these strategies any better, "keep" wins if and only if your >>initial choice was correct (1/3) and "change" wins if and only if it >>was wrong (2/3). >> >>What you *can* do with this extra knowledge is make up a *better >>strategy* than those two. In my extreme example where you get to see >>the car, a good strategy would be "keep my door if and only if it >>contains the car". This *new* strategy wins the car 100% of the >> >> >time. > > >>Now what about the situation you described? The game is the same but >>you get extra information from the behaviour of the host. Can you >> >> >use > > >>it to make up a new strategy? >> >>Hmmmmm.... actually I just noticed something. Gotta think about it, >>will be back when I'm done with that. But I'm gonna submit the above >>now anyway. >> >>Cheers! >>Stefan >> >> >> > > > > > > > > >Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >__________ NOD32 1.1342 (20051228) Information __________ > >This message was checked by NOD32 antivirus system. >http://www.nod32.com > > > > >
414. Another cubing milestone! (sharing)
From: "melchan78" <melchan78@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 02:14:38 -0000

Hi frens,

I was the guy from Malaysia who posted 3 months ago about his first sub-
30 average. Well, I reached another personal milestone today with my
first non-lucky sub-20 time (19.61 secs)! YES!

My next goal is to do a sub-20 average. My current best avg from 1.5
months back is 26.00 secs. That was mainly done with a 3-look LL. I'm
learning OLL right now and knows about 80% of the algorithms at this
moment. My non-lucky sub-20 time was done with a 2-look LL. I'll start
taking averages again once I'm done with all the OLL algo's. Thanks a
lot to the cubing community for sharing ideas and algo's.

I'm on a working assigment in the United States (California) right now
and looking forward to the Exploratorium competition in January. I
won't be competing but I'm eager to meet up with some you guys.

Cheers,
Meng






415. [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 02:21:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > In order to appease Stefan, I propose we play the game this way: > > I put in $5, and you put in $4. The combined $9 is put behind one of > the three doors (or cups, or whatever). I'll let you choose the door. > You choose the door, someone reveals a door without the money (that's > not the door you chose). If the $9 is behind the original door you > chose, you keep the money. If it's behind the other door, I'll keep > the money. We repeat this 100 times. > > I'm not arguing the probabilities of this game anymore. Here's the > game. Do you want to play? If indeed the answer is 1/2, 1/2, then > you'll win $50. If you have ESP and can perceive things, then you'll > win money. I'm prepared to part with up to $500 for this game. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology Nah, that's no good :-) The funny thing about the version I proposed is that even though for the person playing the whole game it feels somewhat like the original game, the probabilities are reversed! In that game, keeping your door gets you 2/3 and switching only 1/3. Damn, I was hoping to win easy 20 bucks from you... Cheers! Stefan
416. [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 02:28:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gustav Fredell <gufr5747@s...> wrote: > > Just to argue a bit more in this thread (which is very silly) I have a > couple of questions: > > Are you suggesting that I still have 1/3, 2/3 (any way) when choosing at > random or always alternating between staying/switching? If you did that > should read 1/2, 1/2. > > /Gustav If you play randomly or alternate evenly, you'll *overall* end up with the car 1/2 of the time. But the *individual* probabilities for "keep" and "switch" stay the same: you'll win 1/3 of all games in which you say "keep", and you'll win 2/3 of all games in which you say "switch". Cheers! Stefan
417. Re: Silicon spray on the plane or in the suitcase ?
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 02:50:52 -0000

Well I got some of the 80 weight, and I like it. My fear was that the heavier weights would be too thick and gunky. But it's not like that at all. It's almost a gel consistency, like Stefan described. It's also cheaper than the 3M silicone spray. So far so good. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eric" <maier@d...> wrote: > > Thanks Stefan, > > Weight is a term describing viscosity. The smaller the weithg number > the lower the viscosity. The higher the weight the greater the viscosity. > > Just another unit of measure as far as I know. > > I'll get some higher weight lube and try it out. > > Thanks, > > Eric > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > The 50 is "too fluid". I haven't used it very often yet but I think it > > drops out of the cube more easily, and I think it feels more "sticky". > > Wet your hands with water, press them against each other and slide > > them against each other. It actually makes it stiffer than when my > > hands are dry. Silicone oil just makes the sliding easier (I believe.. > > . I admit I never really tried that :-). Same with 50 vs 1000, the 50 > > gives me a more sticky feeling I think. > > > > What exactly does the "weight" value describe? It's certainly not the > > weight of the oil itself, my 1000 weighs about the same as my 50, > > certainly not 20 times as much :-) > > > > Cheers! > > STefan > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Eric" <maier@d...> > > wrote: > > > > > > Yes, viscosity / weight are the same idea. > > > > > > Never tried a heavier weight. What do you like better about it? > > > > > > Thanks, > > > > > > Eric > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Does anyone know whether this has to do with the viscosity? And if > > > > yes, what's the correspondence? > > > > > > > > I have two silicone oils, one with viscosity 50 and one with 1000 > > > > (yes, the smallest and largest they had). The 50 is very fluid > > whereas > > > > the 1000 is like gel. I like the 1000 better. > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, christopher_pelley > > > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > I noticed that for silicone oil (such as Shock Oil), there are > > > > > different weights. Do you prefer the lighter or heaver weights? > > > > > > The > > > > > hobby store I visited had 25, 55, and 80 weights available. > > I've > > > > also > > > > > seen a 10-weight online. > > > > > > > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > > > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > > > One of the reasons silicone oil rules :-) > > > > > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
418. [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 03:11:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > As I wrote in response to Gustav, I did 100 trials with no switching > > and won 76 times. > > I think you overestimate our stupidity. > > Cheers! > Stefan David asked me to apologize because he has done nothing to deserve my questioning of his honesty. So here I go. Sorry David, if you say so, I will believe it. Actually getting 76 out of 100 isn't so hard, after all you had 1/3 chance each time, that's not nothing. I haven't computed the odds for it but I guess it's not like it means you're so lucky you should win the lottery every week so that instead of wasting your time trying to convince us with words, you could just fly all of us to your place and we could try your program and get convinced easily. It would also be cool to see research that's not 70 years old. I encourage you to win the lottery a few times and then sponsor some new research. You could also hire a few crackers to shoot down this website which sells ESP stuff: http://www.parascope.com They pretend to believe in this stuff but they say: "Rhine is often popularly remembered as the man who "proved" that psychic powers existed. While he did collect some compelling test results that indicated statistically unlikely accuracy among his subjects, subsequent examinations of his work have concluded that procedural flaws and probability loopholes invalidate any claims of proof." How can they dare to pretend they advocate ESP and the like if they attack completely honest and professional Mr Rhine? What a bad world this is... Cheers! Stefan P.S. Is somebody capable of computing the odds for winning those 76 out of 100?

421. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 19:23:57 -0800

If you have a 1/3 probability of winning each time, and out of 100
trials you won 76, the probability of that happening is:

(1/3)^76*(2/3)^24*(100 nCr 76)

Where 100 nCr 76 is 100 choose 76. I think that's correct, but I might
be wrong, but of course, that number is definitely really small. Let's
compete the probability that someone can win 76 or more times.

Sum(i=76 to 100): (1/3)^i*(2/3)^(100-i)*(100 nCr i)

Using Mathematica, I got 3*10^(-18).

With that type of probability, I'd risk my testicles. And Leyan's too.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Dec 28, 2005, at 7:11 PM, Stefan Pochmann wrote:

> P.S. Is somebody capable of computing the odds for winning those 76
> out of 100?

to it :) I'll bet my testicles too.

/Gustav

426. Re: mefferts.com 4x4 and 5x5
From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 04:27:09 -0000

You can actually buy 2 different 5x5x5 cubes at Mefferts. Theres the Eastsheen 5x which are stickered and differently constructed but equally nice as a Rubiks 5x5x5. The other is the Tiled Mefferts Professor which is exactly the same as a Rubiks 5x just with Tiles instead of stickers. Neither puzzle uses B.O.Y color scheme. The 4x4x4 at Mefferts is an Eastsheen. "better than the store bought cubes?" It depends who you ask, I like them all but I dont speedsolve the bigger cubes (at least not very well). I can tell you they are all quality puzzles. Good Luck! -mike --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mattjs522" <matt100@g...> wrote: > > Are the 4x4 and 5x5 from mefferts.com good cubes? are they better than > the store bought rubiks cubes. >
427. Re: Error in provided algs
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, ddollard@...
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 20:39:22 -0800 (PST)

that case 2nd row last one, i do it like this, with the tredges at FL and FR U2u2 R2r2 F2 u2 F2 R2r2 U2u2 and notice the little u in between the F's which means only the u slice, not U. the case number 1 that u drew there is acutally case # 2, but the tredge has been flipped upside down, if you do L' F U' you will see that you have case number 2 with FL on FU and FR on FD or what i do is instead of placing them next to each other, i place them two slots away (like i would first do R2 x2 on your example)and do the same thing as case 1 and 2 except the first and last move are 1/2 turns instead of 1/4. i don't know if that makes sense but if you do an R2, you should see how its the same case as number 2 but it is an extra slot away. the second example is also a similar situation, its acutally #7 but a tredge is flipped upside down, you can remove it and put it in the other way using the same move from above. hope this helps. ----- Original Message ---- From: Dwayne <ddollard@...> To: perscription_death@... Sent: Wednesday, December 28, 2005 17:23:44 Subject: Error in provided algs Sorry my bad, Execution error. Can you verify the top row far right? Shouldn't the MUU2 be U2? Also here is the attachment Thanks Dwayne [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
428. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Explaining the math behind cubing to kids
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 12:22:36 +0530

Ya Evan is right. Most ppl dont have the concept of "cubies". Explain that surely to the kids. Also what i try to do when explaining to others is the abstract concept as to why any algorithm works. I say that if u do a move say X and then Y and then if u reverse the moves, like X Y Y' X', then nothing will happen to the cube. But if u undo the first move first then u get somethign like X Y X' Y' and this changes the state of the cube. Ofcourse dont use the ""X" nad "Y" during ur talk or u'll confuse the kids. And surely if the kids are bright then try to touch upon the concept of commutators. From what i have seen, it surely is a little tough at first making ppl understand commutators but once thats done its easy to explain the whole last layer. Also show different shapes on the cubes to entertain the kids..or maybe teach them how to get to the patterns from a solved cube and make them do it. It'll be a sort of hands-on for them and they'll surely get interested. Keep us informed how the tutorials go :) Sachin. On 12/29/05, Evan Gates <evan.gates@...> wrote: > I think one of the most important thing to point out to non cubers is that > the cube is made up of the smaller "cubies" if you will. Alot of people > think that each sticker can be moved individually. Another good one is the > difference between orientation and permutation. Then, if you want to be > really ambitious, you can try to explain commutators, but I've never found a > good way to explain it in speech form, I always have to sit down and show > someone. And you have to give them a website that they can visit to learn > more about the cube. > > Just a couple of ideas, > -Evan > > Until next time, Happy Cubing > http://www.deepcube.net > > > On 12/28/05, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> wrote: > > > > You could calculate how much of your lifetime you've already wasted > > for cubing :-). And then argue that you haven't wasted enough because > > your goal is to reach every possible state. Imagine... > > > > - you could twist (the corner tips) with the speed of light > > - you'd twist your whole life (assume 100 years) > > - never visit a state twice so you don't waste time > > > > How much of the cube space would you visit? If I didn't make a > > mistake, it's about 35.7% which I think is a very nice number cause > > it's large enough to be graspable and doesn't reach 100%. > > > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hey guys, > > > > > > Someone asked me to do a demonstration of the cube for some kids, > > and > > > tell some nice things about it... The kids are about 11-12 years > > old. > > > Does anyone have good ideas about what I should tell them? And, more > > > important: how I should tell it to them, so they would understand? > > > > > > Thanks! > > > > > > Joël. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ------------------------------ > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > > > > - Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube>" > > on the web. > > > > - To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com<speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com?subject=Unsubscribe> > > > > - Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of > > Service <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/>. > > > > > > ------------------------------ > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! 430. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Explaining the math behind cubing to kids
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 13:17:04 +0530

Ya my mistake :) On 12/29/05, Evan Gates <evan.gates@...> wrote: > aren't algorithms in the form X Y X' Y' commutators? or am do I just have > the wrong name paired up with the wrong idea? > > -E > > > On 12/28/05, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...> wrote: > > > > Ya Evan is right. Most ppl dont have the concept of "cubies". Explain > > that surely to the kids. > > > > Also what i try to do when explaining to others is the abstract > > concept as to why any algorithm works. I say that if u do a move say X > > and then Y and then if u reverse the moves, like X Y Y' X', then > > nothing will happen to the cube. But if u undo the first move first > > then u get somethign like X Y X' Y' and this changes the state of the > > cube. Ofcourse dont use the ""X" nad "Y" during ur talk or u'll > > confuse the kids. > > > > And surely if the kids are bright then try to touch upon the concept > > of commutators. From what i have seen, it surely is a little tough at > > first making ppl understand commutators but once thats done its easy > > to explain the whole last layer. > > > > Also show different shapes on the cubes to entertain the kids..or > > maybe teach them how to get to the patterns from a solved cube and > > make them do it. It'll be a sort of hands-on for them and they'll > > surely get interested. > > > > Keep us informed how the tutorials go :) > > > > Sachin. > > > > On 12/29/05, Evan Gates <evan.gates@...> wrote: > > > I think one of the most important thing to point out to non cubers is > > that > > > the cube is made up of the smaller "cubies" if you will. Alot of people > > > think that each sticker can be moved individually. Another good one is > > the > > > difference between orientation and permutation. Then, if you want to be > > > really ambitious, you can try to explain commutators, but I've never > > found a > > > good way to explain it in speech form, I always have to sit down and > > show > > > someone. And you have to give them a website that they can visit to > > learn > > > more about the cube. > > > > > > Just a couple of ideas, > > > -Evan > > > > > > Until next time, Happy Cubing > > > http://www.deepcube.net > > > > > > > > > On 12/28/05, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@gmx.de> wrote: > > > > > > > > You could calculate how much of your lifetime you've already wasted > > > > for cubing :-). And then argue that you haven't wasted enough because > > > > your goal is to reach every possible state. Imagine... > > > > > > > > - you could twist (the corner tips) with the speed of light > > > > - you'd twist your whole life (assume 100 years) > > > > - never visit a state twice so you don't waste time > > > > > > > > How much of the cube space would you visit? If I didn't make a > > > > mistake, it's about 35.7% which I think is a very nice number cause > > > > it's large enough to be graspable and doesn't reach 100%. > > > > > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort > > > > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > Hey guys, > > > > > > > > > > Someone asked me to do a demonstration of the cube for some kids, > > > > and > > > > > tell some nice things about it... The kids are about 11-12 years > > > > old. > > > > > Does anyone have good ideas about what I should tell them? And, more > > > > > important: how I should tell it to them, so they would understand? > > > > > > > > > > Thanks! > > > > > > > > > > Joël. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ------------------------------ > > > > YAHOO! 431. Overmoving fingers
From: "Anssi Vanhala" <mahtianssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 07:57:45 -0000

I'm just interested to know how many of you cubers have overmoving
fingers. At least my pinkies are quite much overmoving and click-clack
almost as much as my cubes.





432. [Speed cubing group] Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 08:37:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Bob, > > You switched half the time, and won about half the games. > > Wasn't that supposed to be false? > > Wow! Who woulda thunk it! No, that is indeed supposed to be true. My claim was that switching results in a win 2/3 of the time and staying with the original door results in a win 1/3 of the time. Instead, my results were 64% and 32% respectively (sorry, I was off by 2.7% and 1.3%). Of course, with a "random" strategy (switching half the time and keeping your choice half the time), you should win (1/3)*(1/2) + (2/3)*(1/2) = 1/2 of the time. ~ Bob
433. Re: (Off topic)3 doors...
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 08:39:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > I'm curious, what percentage of the time will the game be won if the > computer contestant switches it's choice 2/3s of the time? In theory, it should be (2/3)*(2/3) + (1/3)*(1/3) = 5/9 of the time. ~ Bob

435. Re: nice alg and finger trick
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 09:29:52 -0000

Could you make a video for me please? I'd like to see how you perform this. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Try this for OLL (inverse to set up): > r' U' (F x) R' U' (l2' x) U L U' R' U x > > During (F x) regrip with the left hand so that your ring finger, not > your middle finger ends up on B. Then after the R' pull U' with left > index finger, and l2' with left middle finger followed by left index > finger. Bob, you should love this one (according to your site it's > your second-slowest OLL case :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan >

440. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Silicon spray on the plane or in the suitcase ?
From: Rune Wesström <rune.wesstrom@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 13:05:26 +0100

Here I beat you; I have Three silicone oils, one with the viscosity 100 (as milk), one with 1000 (as gele) and one with 10000 (as treacle). The second is the best one, but the third is almost as good. The viscosity is measured in "stokes", evidently an old measure and I can´t find any definition on it. (I guess; the elasticity module. In diagrams the logarithms are shown). R ----- Original Message ----- From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@gmx.de> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, December 28, 2005 11:13 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Silicon spray on the plane or in the suitcase ? > Does anyone know whether this has to do with the viscosity? And if > yes, what's the correspondence? > > I have two silicone oils, one with viscosity 50 and one with 1000 > (yes, the smallest and largest they had). The 50 is very fluid whereas > the 1000 is like gel. I like the 1000 better. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, christopher_pelley > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > I noticed that for silicone oil (such as Shock Oil), there are > > different weights. 441. New way to do the H-Permutation
From: Joël van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 12:17:02 -0000

Hey everybody,

This might be old news, but I found a way to make my H-permutation
faster... I never really liked the H-permutation, but now it's ok...
Some of you will still beat me, though..

I was inspired by Bob Burton, who does the M2' with his (left)
middle and ring finger. I now do it with my middle finger, starting
with the tip of my finger at the UB edge sticker. However, it's
really awkward to do M2' that way... So I actually start with an L,
then place my finger, and do L(L'M2') at the same time. So the alg
becomes:

L(L'M2') U L(L'M2') U2 L(L'M2')U L(L'M2')

Ok, I know it looks ugly, but it's just a way of writing it to show
how I execute it :). I don't have a webcam here (I am at my parents
house), but I'll make a video soon.

See you!

Joël.

Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 13:27:04 +0100

Yes, the thread is going to infinity. Btw., what shape should a thread going there have (not breaking by it´s own weight)? 443. Re: [Speed cubing group] Professor Algorithm Needed
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 12:37:30 -0000

I just tried this (Rr U) * 5, and it doesn't seem to work. Are you sure that's the algorithm? I know (R2 u) * 5 moves four edges around the equator, but (Rr U) * 5 just produces a scramble for me! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Try (Rr U) *5 with your two unsolved edges in UF and UB (place the two > solved pieces (edge center and edge wing) on the right for both of > them). Then you'll have 3 edges that can be easily solved. > > Good luck ! > Gilles. > > 2005/12/27, cube_padiwan <ncp_3@m...>: > > Hello everyone! I've tried but have been unable to find an algorithm or > > tutorial for matching the three pieces of the last two edges of a > > Professor (5x5x5) Cube. I'm trying to solve the Professor cube by using > > the method where you solve the centers first, then match all the edge > > pieces together, which turns the Cube into a 3x3x3. I can get all the > > edge pieces matched together except for the pieces of the last two > > edges! This is very aggravating! If anyone knows how to do this or has > > a link to a site whcih explains this, your help would be very much > > appreciated! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

445. Re: [Speed cubing group] Professor Algorithm Needed
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 15:34:55 +0100

Oh I'm sorry, the alg is (Rr U2) * 5 This one is correct ;-) This version of the alg is for speedsolving, if you want a purer version so that it doesn't mess the corners), do (r U2) *5 (r is the 2 layer counting from the right). Good luck ! Gilles. 2005/12/29, christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>: > I just tried this (Rr U) * 5, and it doesn't seem to work. Are you > sure that's the algorithm? I know (R2 u) * 5 moves four edges > around the equator, but (Rr U) * 5 just produces a scramble for me! > > Chris > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > Try (Rr U) *5 with your two unsolved edges in UF and UB (place the > two > > solved pieces (edge center and edge wing) on the right for both of > > them). Then you'll have 3 edges that can be easily solved. > > > > Good luck ! > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/27, cube_padiwan <ncp_3@m...>: > > > Hello everyone! I've tried but have been unable to find an > algorithm or > > > tutorial for matching the three pieces of the last two edges of a > > > Professor (5x5x5) Cube. I'm trying to solve the Professor cube > by using > > > the method where you solve the centers first, then match all the > edge > > > pieces together, which turns the Cube into a 3x3x3. I can get > all the > > > edge pieces matched together except for the pieces of the last > two > > > edges! This is very aggravating! If anyone knows how to do this > or has > > > a link to a site whcih explains this, your help would be very > much > > > appreciated! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
446. Re: [Speed cubing group] Professor Algorithm Needed
From: christopher_pelley <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 16:07:27 -0000

Thanks, that works! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Oh I'm sorry, the alg is (Rr U2) * 5 > This one is correct ;-) > > This version of the alg is for speedsolving, if you want a purer > version so that it doesn't mess the corners), do (r U2) *5 (r is the 2 > layer counting from the right). > > Good luck ! > Gilles. > > 2005/12/29, christopher_pelley <no_reply@...m>: > > I just tried this (Rr U) * 5, and it doesn't seem to work. Are you > > sure that's the algorithm? I know (R2 u) * 5 moves four edges > > around the equator, but (Rr U) * 5 just produces a scramble for me! > > > > Chris > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > > > Try (Rr U) *5 with your two unsolved edges in UF and UB (place the > > two > > > solved pieces (edge center and edge wing) on the right for both of > > > them). Then you'll have 3 edges that can be easily solved. > > > > > > Good luck ! > > > Gilles. > > > > > > 2005/12/27, cube_padiwan <ncp_3@m...>: > > > > Hello everyone! I've tried but have been unable to find an > > algorithm or > > > > tutorial for matching the three pieces of the last two edges of a > > > > Professor (5x5x5) Cube. I'm trying to solve the Professor cube > > by using > > > > the method where you solve the centers first, then match all the > > edge > > > > pieces together, which turns the Cube into a 3x3x3. I can get > > all the > > > > edge pieces matched together except for the pieces of the last > > two > > > > edges! This is very aggravating! If anyone knows how to do this > > or has > > > > a link to a site whcih explains this, your help would be very > > much > > > > appreciated! > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
447. Re: New way to do the H-Permutation
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 16:16:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Joël van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > L(L'M2') U L(L'M2') U2 L(L'M2')U L(L'M2') That looks very nice! I must admit first I thought I had done this before, because your explanation sounded similar to what I've been doing: L2 (LM)2', Also pulling with my left middle finger, putting it on the FU sticker after the L2. This way my right hand stays fixed and only does the U's while the left hand does all the other turns. I think it has to do with that it's easier to rotate your hand "towards" you than "away" from you. But your way looks even better. Gotta try it... Cheers! Stefan

In diagrams the logarithms are shown). > R Woah, I'd love to try that 10000... though, probably not right away in my best cube :-). And searching for 10 million (!) still finds three results, one speaking of "silicone *gum*": http://tinyurl.com/czagb Cheers! Stefan
449. Re: nice alg and finger trick
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 16:52:00 -0000

Sure. I also made one for my original way of doing it. Here are three algs: My previously described way: r' U' (F x) R' U' (l2' x) U L U' R' U x My older way: r' U' (F x) R' U' (R l) U L U' R' U x Clean setup (i.e. inverse without cube rotations): B' R B L' B' R2 U R U' B L And the two algs on video: http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/oll49.wmv (369 kb) Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Could you make a video for me please? I'd like to see how you perform > this. > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Try this for OLL (inverse to set up): > > r' U' (F x) R' U' (l2' x) U L U' R' U x > > > > During (F x) regrip with the left hand so that your ring finger, not > > your middle finger ends up on B. Then after the R' pull U' with left > > index finger, and l2' with left middle finger followed by left index > > finger. Bob, you should love this one (according to your site it's > > your second-slowest OLL case :-) > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > >

452. Re: nice alg and finger trick
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 18:32:02 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > finger. Bob, you should love this one (according to your site it's > > > your second-slowest OLL case :-) Also, try this one for your slowest (case 56, 3.167 seconds): (R' U' R U' R' U2 R) (F R U R' U' F') And for case 54 try this: y2 (R U R' U R U2 R') (F R U R' U' F') Notice I only separate it in the middle because it's two independent LL algs. But the R' F is of course really a finger trick. Cheers! Stefan

I found the definition of a stoke (if it could be of any interest): CGS-unit for cinematical viscosity with the notation St. 1 St = 10000m2/s ----- Original Message ----- From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Thursday, December 29, 2005 5:25 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Silicon spray on the plane or in the suitcase ? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Rune Wesström <rune. wesstrom@h...> wrote: > > Here I beat you; I have Three silicone oils, one with the viscosity 100 (as milk), one with 1000 (as gele) and one with 10000 (as treacle) . 454. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error in provided algs
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 11:37:58 -0800 (PST)

hey dwayne did this help? ----- Original Message ---- From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com; ddollard@... Sent: Wednesday, December 28, 2005 20:39:22 Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error in provided algs that case 2nd row last one, i do it like this, with the tredges at FL and FR U2u2 R2r2 F2 u2 F2 R2r2 U2u2 and notice the little u in between the F's which means only the u slice, not U. the case number 1 that u drew there is acutally case # 2, but the tredge has been flipped upside down, if you do L' F U' you will see that you have case number 2 with FL on FU and FR on FD or what i do is instead of placing them next to each other, i place them two slots away (like i would first do R2 x2 on your example)and do the same thing as case 1 and 2 except the first and last move are 1/2 turns instead of 1/4. i don't know if that makes sense but if you do an R2, you should see how its the same case as number 2 but it is an extra slot away. the second example is also a similar situation, its acutally #7 but a tredge is flipped upside down, you can remove it and put it in the other way using the same move from above. hope this helps. ----- Original Message ---- From: Dwayne <ddollard@...> To: perscription_death@... Sent: Wednesday, December 28, 2005 17:23:44 Subject: Error in provided algs Sorry my bad, Execution error. Can you verify the top row far right? Shouldn't the MUU2 be U2? Also here is the attachment Thanks Dwayne [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. You let it play > by itself? > > I did my little thing so that a person could play - so this claim > wouldn't apply: > "They [the random number generator] could accidently line up and the > computer contestent could choose correctly 100% of the time, and > switching 100% of the time it would lose 100% of the time." > > And the answers are at the bottom in case you would like to check > them out. All predetermined - so that you can't say that your > guesses are somehow affecting which door I put the car behind for > the next game. > > And it doesn't ask whether you want to switch each time... to take > care of this claim: > "If the computer takes longer to ask you if you want to switch after > you chose correctly this could be perceived, consciously or > unconsciously, and affect your choice." > > If you want, choose your strategy after your guesses... 458. Re: nice alg and finger trick
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 22:18:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Thank you, that is very nice. I MUST switch. BTW, my website is out > of date and that is instead my slowest case. :) Hehe, great :-). And here's now a faster video: http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/oll49_fast.wmv The twisting is 1.50 seconds, i.e. a bit more than twice as fast as yours. This does not include the regrip for the x at the end, with that it's 1.77 seconds. I had also found another nice way for this OLL case: R' U' F R' F' R F U R U' R' F' R This might actually be faster for me, but I noticed I get confused and make mistakes because I'm using this alg for your case 23: R' U' F U R U' R' F' R That's the same but without a (R' F' R F) in the middle. You're using the same alg, just from a different angle: (L' d') (R d) (L U') (r' U' r) Adding (B' R' B R) at the appropriate place gives you this alternative alg for case 49: (L' d') (R (B' R' B R) d) (L U') (r' U' r) Since you do your OLL 23 in 1.60 and your OLL 49 in 3.10, all you have to do is those extra four moves in less than 1.50 ;-) Cheers! Stefan
459. Reaction Time
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 14:28:21 -0800

Hey Everyone,

I was just curious what the reaction times of people were. Try this
game:

http://www.fingertime.com/bullettime.php

I'm not so great. My best so far is 194 ms and I'm usually around 230
to 250 ms. I'm sure there are some people here who can get around 150
ms.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



460. blast from the past: solution poster
From: "Jeff Soesbe" <yeff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 22:41:38 -0000

All -

25 years ago, when I was a young cuber, I bought a solution poster
and tacked it to the door of my room.

My mom has been cleaning out the house, and for christmas took the
old poster off the door, patched it up, laminated it and mailed it
to me!

It's an interesting solution - edges first (top layer edges, middle
layer edges, bottom edge permute then orient), then corners (place
front, place back, orient right, orient left). The solution is
entirely built from commutators, using certain commutators for
different steps.

The solution is credited to: "Jeffrey Adams, who has a PhD in
mathematics (Lie Groups) from Yale University" with "Many thanks are
owed to Matthew and Tevin Abeshouse, who did the design and graphics
for this poster, and to Don Kersey, with whom most of this material
was discovered."

I'll bring it along to the Exploratorium contest and maybe we can
get some posterboard and put it up on a stand somewhere for people
to check out.

see you in San Francisco!

yeff

463. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Reaction Time
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 14:46:33 -0800

I think the people with ridiculous scores cheat. Anyway, to bring this to cubing, do you think a fast reaction time helps with case recognition while solving the cube? Generally, we should be looking ahead so that we know what's coming... but sometimes you do a really fast OLL and you're hit with a 3-cycle that's facing right at you with the correct face. Is it costing us 200 ms to decide clockwise or counter-clockwise, does it take more time than that because we have to recognize something more complex? 465. Sub-16s solve!
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: Lista Speed Cubing <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 19:51:52 -0300 (ART)

Hey folks

Well, I know this is not very fast, many of you can average faster than this, but I'm happy to announce that I made my first sub-16s solve! The time was 15.78s, with this scramble:

F' D F2 D2 R2 L U F2 D B R' L D L B U L U' L U' F' B2 L R F'

My solution was like this:
Cross: (y') F' D' R' D' R' (5)
1st pair: (y) U L' U L U (y) L' U L (8)
2nd pair: (y2) R U' R' (y) U' L' U L (7)
3rd pair: (y) L' U2 L U' L' U L (7)
4th pair: U' R U' R' (4)
OLL: (y') R U x' R U' R' U x U' R' (8)
PLL: (U) R U R' U' R' F R2 U' R' U' R U R' F' (14)

Total: 53 moves in 15.78 seconds = ~3.36moves/second

I know, I know, too many cube rotations...I have to work on that...but that slve was GOOD! : )

Pedro


---------------------------------
Yahoo! doce lar. Faça do Yahoo! sua homepage.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



466. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Reaction Time
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 19:54:23 -0300 (ART)

I think so. On that game, you just have to see the bullet or hear the sound and click the mouse. On cubing, you have to see a pattern (between A LOT of them) and decide which alg to use (that also is not just one move). But I think people with good reflexes are good on cubing. Pedro Tyson Mao <tmao@...> escreveu: I think the people with ridiculous scores cheat. Anyway, to bring this to cubing, do you think a fast reaction time helps with case recognition while solving the cube? Generally, we should be looking ahead so that we know what's coming... but sometimes you do a really fast OLL and you're hit with a 3-cycle that's facing right at you with the correct face. Is it costing us 200 ms to decide clockwise or counter-clockwise, does it take more time than that because we have to recognize something more complex? 468. Rubik's WC trophy on Ebay (?)
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: Lista Speed Cubing <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 23:04:07 +0000 (GMT)

I saw this thing on ebay, and since I wasn't there at the WC, I'd ask to you:

http://cgi.ebay.com/Rubiks-World-Championship-TROPHY-rubiks-rubic-cube_W0QQitemZ6026014611QQcategoryZ19187QQrdZ1QQcmdZViewItem

Is this the actual trophy? Or is just someone wanting to make some money with a false product?
